Xi Jinping:
Xi Jinping is a Chinese politician who has been serving as the General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party since 2012, the President of the People's Republic of China since 2013, and the Chairman of the Central Military Commission, thus becoming the top leader of China.  He is often seen as one of the most powerful leaders in modern Chinese history since Mao Zedong. 

Born on June 15, 1953, in Beijing, Xi comes from a family with close ties to the Chinese communist revolution.  His father, Xi Zhongxun, was a revolutionary veteran and an important figure in the Communist Party.  However, during the Cultural Revolution, Xi Jinping experienced a difficult youth when his father was purged, and he himself was sent to the countryside for "re-education through labor" as a member of the Red Guards.  He lived in a village in the Shaanxi province, where he did manual labor. 

He then started his studies at Tsinghua University, where he obtained a Ph. D.  in law and Marxist ideology.  His political career began in the 1980s.  He quickly rose through the party ranks in the provinces of Fujian, Zhejiang, and finally Shanghai before being promoted at the national level. 

Elected General Secretary of the Communist Party in November 2012, Xi Jinping launched a series of reforms aiming to centralize power in his hands and combat corruption, an initiative that led to the downfall of many high-ranking officials.  At the same time, he promoted the "Belt and Road Initiative," an infrastructure project aimed at enhancing connectivity and economic cooperation between China and other countries in various regions around the world. 

Under his leadership, the Chinese government has also strengthened censorship and media control, as well as citizen surveillance.  He has also defended China's sovereignty and territorial integrity, sometimes leading to tensions with neighbors and foreign powers. 

In 2018, presidential term limits were removed, allowing Xi to remain in power beyond the previously set two five-year terms.  This decision was seen as a sign of his increased power and desire to lead China indefinitely. 

Xi Jinping has played a key role in shaping Chinese economic policy, aiming to maintain the country's economic growth while addressing challenges of modernization, rising inequalities, and environmental issues. 

With an ambitious foreign policy, he has sought to position China as a major global power while managing complex relationships with the United States and other nations.  His presidency is characterized by strengthened nationalism, consolidation of personal power, and stricter control over society and the economy.
Narendra Modi:
Narendra Damodardas Modi, born on September 17, 1950 in Vadnagar, is an Indian politician, a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), the Hindu nationalist party.  He has been serving as the 14th and current Prime Minister of India since 2014.  Before becoming Prime Minister, he was the Chief Minister of Gujarat from 2001 to 2014. 

Modi was born and raised in a family of tea sellers from the Ganchi caste, traditionally considered a lower caste in Indian society.  He earned a Bachelor of Arts in Political Science from the University of Delhi and a Master of Arts from the University of Gujarat.  In his youth, Modi was an activist in the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a Hindu nationalist paramilitary organization.  He later joined the BJP, and his political career progressed rapidly within the party. 

As Chief Minister of Gujarat, Modi implemented policies to encourage economic growth and private investment.  He was credited with transforming the economy of Gujarat, but was also criticized for his handling of the 2002 riots in Gujarat, which resulted in the deaths of over 1,000 people, mostly Muslims.  Modi denied any responsibility, and in 2012, an inquiry supervised by the Supreme Court found no evidence to prosecute Modi. 

His victory in the 2014 election as Prime Minister was historic, as the BJP secured an absolute majority in parliament, a first in 30 years in the country.  Under Modi, the Indian government launched numerous economic reforms aimed at liberalizing the Indian economy, including the implementation of a goods and services tax system and various initiatives to promote digitization and modernization of infrastructure. 

His foreign policy, often described as pragmatic, aims to strengthen ties with major countries around the world, and he is a strong advocate of multilateralism.  Modi is also known for his use of social media to communicate with the public. 

However, his second term, which began in 2019, has been marked by controversy, notably due to the enactment of the Citizenship Amendment Act, seen as discriminatory towards Muslims, and the revocation of Article 370, ending the special autonomy of Jammu and Kashmir. 

Despite being a divisive figure, Modi remains a highly influential political figure in India, with his popularity largely supported by his efforts to promote a sense of Hindu nationalism and his image as a pragmatic and results-oriented leader.
Joko Widodo:
Joko Widodo, often nicknamed "Jokowi", is an Indonesian politician born on June 21, 1961 in Surakarta (also known as Solo), in the province of Central Java.  He is the 7th President of the Republic of Indonesia, having taken office on October 20, 2014. 

Raised in a modest family, Jokowi has long been seen as a man of the people.  His father was a carpenter and his mother sold wood at local markets.  He studied forestry at Gadjah Mada University in Yogyakarta, one of Indonesia's most respected universities, where he obtained a bachelor's degree in 1985. 

After his studies, Jokowi joined his uncle's furniture company and later started his own business in the furniture industry.  His success as an entrepreneur marked the beginning of his public career as he became known for his pragmatic approach and business sense. 

Jokowi entered politics in 2005 when he was elected mayor of his hometown, Surakarta.  His innovative approach to city leadership, which focused on transparency, public service, and urban development, earned him national recognition.  As mayor, he transformed Surakarta into a model of urban regeneration and participatory governance, helping revitalize the city center and improve public services. 

In 2012, his political career took a major turn when he was elected Governor of Jakarta, the capital of Indonesia.  In this position, he continued his reform efforts and focused on improving urban infrastructure, combating corruption, and reducing flooding, a major issue in Jakarta. 

In 2014, Jokowi won the presidential election, embodying the hopes of many Indonesians eager for change and reform within the government.  Among his notable policies as President, he has focused on infrastructure development, improving health and education, and boosting the Indonesian economy.  He is also known for his "mental revolution" policy, aimed at promoting discipline, hard work, and honesty among Indonesians. 

Jokowi has also shown strong determination to preserve Indonesia's sovereignty over its islands and territorial waters by strengthening maritime security and taking strict measures against foreign fishing vessels operating illegally in the country's exclusive economic zones. 

Re-elected for a second term in 2019, Jokowi continues to play a crucial role in Indonesian politics and in the country's economic development, while facing challenges such as managing the COVID-19 pandemic and internal political tensions. 

Joko Widodo is widely seen as a political figure outside the traditional system, who has built his career on his "self-made man" identity and his closeness to the Indonesian people.
Mamnoon Hussain:
Mamnoon Hussain was a Pakistani politician who served as the 12th President of Pakistan from September 9, 2013, to September 9, 2018.  Born on December 23, 1940, in Agra, in what was then British India, his family emigrated to Pakistan following the partition of India in 1947. 

Hussain studied at the Institute of Business Administration (IBA) in Karachi where he earned a degree in commerce in the 1960s.  After his studies, he joined the family business and later made his mark in the textile sector. 

His political career began with his membership in the Pakistan Muslim League (Nawaz) (PML-N), a conservative political party and one of the main political forces in the country.  In the 1990s, he was appointed to the Sindh Provincial Council, where he briefly served as an advisor to the Governor of Sindh. 

Mamnoon Hussain remained under the political radar for much of his career until he ran for presidency after the outgoing President Asif Ali Zardari in 2013.  With the support of the PML-N, which at the time had the majority in the National Assembly after the 2013 general elections, Hussain was elected President of Pakistan. 

As president, Mamnoon Hussain's role was primarily ceremonial due to the parliamentary structure of the Pakistani government where executive power is exercised by the Prime Minister.  Nevertheless, as head of state, he played a role in promoting national unity and represented Pakistan on the international stage. 

His tenure as president was relatively quiet and without major political incidents.  He continued the policy of presidential neutrality and served his full term until September 2018, after which he retired from active politics. 

Mamnoon Hussain passed away on July 14, 2021, at the age of 80 after a battle with cancer.  He leaves behind a legacy as a devoted public servant and a president who maintained his dignity and integrity throughout his public life.
Sheikh Hasina:
Sheikh Hasina, born on September 28, 1947 in Tungipara, is a Bangladeshi politician, member of the Bangladesh Awami League, one of the country's two main political parties.  She has served as the Prime Minister of Bangladesh multiple times and is recognized as one of the most influential political figures in recent Bangladeshi history. 

The eldest daughter of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, the founding father of Bangladesh and its first president, Hasina witnessed political struggles from a young age that led to the country's independence in 1971.  She was educated at the University of Dhaka, where she obtained a bachelor's degree in history and a master's degree in philosophy. 

Her life was marked by tragedy when most of her family, including her father, mother, and three brothers, were assassinated during a military coup on August 15, 1975.  Hasina was abroad at that time, which likely saved her life.  She went into exile in India until her return to Bangladesh in 1981. 

Upon her return, she quickly assumed leadership of the Awami League and became a prominent opposition figure against the successive military regimes that ruled the country after her father's assassination.  Sheikh Hasina campaigned for a return to democracy and was arrested multiple times for her activities. 

Hasina was first elected Prime Minister of Bangladesh in 1996, and her government was credited with numerous economic and social improvements, although her time in power was also marked by accusations of corruption.  She lost the elections in 2001 but returned to power in 2009 after a landslide electoral victory.  She was re-elected in 2014 in controversial elections boycotted by the opposition and again in 2018. 

Under her governance, Bangladesh has experienced significant economic growth and improvements in social indicators, including a reduction in poverty and progress towards gender equality.  However, her administration has been criticized for its alleged authoritarian approach, restrictions on freedom of expression and the press, as well as human rights violations. 

Sheikh Hasina has also been internationally recognized, receiving awards for her contribution to Bangladesh's development and her efforts in combating climate change.  She remains a key figure in Bangladeshi politics, currently leading the Awami League and the government of Bangladesh.
Shinzo Abe:
Shinzo Abe was born on September 21, 1954 in Tokyo, Japan.  He came from a influential political family: his grandfather, Nobusuke Kishi, was Prime Minister of Japan in the 1950s, and his father, Shintaro Abe, was Minister of Foreign Affairs.  This political lineage certainly played a role in Shinzo Abe's career. 

Abe studied political science at Seikei University in Tokyo before continuing his studies in the United States at the University of Southern California.  Upon returning to Japan, he worked in the steel industry with Kobe Steel Ltd before following in his family's footsteps in politics. 

He was first elected to the House of Representatives of Japan in 1993, representing the Yamaguchi Prefecture.  As a member of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), he quickly climbed the political ranks.  He held several ministerial positions, including that of Secretary General of the LDP. 

Shinzo Abe served as Prime Minister of Japan twice.  His first term began in September 2006, after the resignation of Junichiro Koizumi.  However, due to health issues and various scandals affecting his cabinet, he resigned in September 2007, after only one year in office. 

He made a political comeback and was re-elected as Prime Minister in December 2012.  During his second term, he was known for his economic policy known as "Abenomics," which aimed to revitalize the stagnant Japanese economy through a mix of fiscal stimulus, monetary easing, and structural reforms.  His administration was also marked by a firm stance on foreign and defense policy, particularly in response to the rise of China and tensions with North Korea. 

Shinzo Abe emphasized constitutional revisionism, advocating for an amendment to Japan's pacifist constitution to allow for an expansion of the country's military capabilities in a "proactive defense" perspective.  Despite these controversial efforts, he did not succeed in formally amending Japan's pacifist constitution during his term. 

His political longevity allowed him to become the longest-serving Prime Minister of Japan in terms of consecutive days in power.  However, he announced his resignation in August 2020 for health reasons, specifically issues related to chronic ulcerative colitis. 

On July 8, 2022, during a political event in Nara, Shinzo Abe tragically passed away after being shot by a gunman.  His death sparked shock and mourning reactions worldwide, and his influence on modern Japanese politics continues to be a subject of discussion and analysis.
Benigno Aquino III:
Benigno Simeon Cojuangco Aquino III, commonly known as "Noynoy" Aquino or "PNoy", was a Filipino politician who served as the 15th President of the Republic of the Philippines from June 30, 2010, to June 30, 2016.  Born on February 8, 1960, in Manila and passing away on June 24, 2021, he was a member of an influential political family, the Aquinos, and the son of former President Corazon Aquino and Senator Benigno Aquino Jr. 

His father was a leader of the opposition to dictator Ferdinand Marcos and was assassinated in 1983 upon his return from exile in the United States, an event that precipitated the events leading to the People Power Revolution (EDSA Revolution) in February 1986, which ousted Marcos and brought his mother, Corazon Aquino, to the presidency. 

Benigno Aquino III was raised in a family dedicated to politics.  He pursued higher education at the Ateneo de Manila University, where he earned a degree in economics.  After years away from politics working in the private sector, he became a member of the House of Representatives, representing the 2nd district of Tarlac from 1998 to 2007. 

Subsequently, he was elected to the Philippine Senate in 2007, and in 2009, following his mother's death, his political profile increased, with significant public support for his presidential candidacy.  Ultimately, he declared his candidacy for the 2010 presidential elections. 

As president, Aquino focused on combating corruption and fostering economic development.  His administration was characterized by a period of stable economic growth for the Philippines, with improvements in infrastructure and foreign investment.  He also initiated the peace process with Islamist insurgents in Mindanao, leading to a historic peace agreement with the Moro Islamic Liberation Front. 

His efforts to fight corruption were exemplified by the impeachment and removal of Chief Justice Renato Corona in 2012.  However, his presidency was also criticized for some of his failures, including perceived inadequate handling of the super typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda) in 2013, which caused significant loss of life and damages. 

Although he left office with relatively high approval ratings, criticisms of his governance persisted after his presidency, particularly regarding some of the issues he failed to address, such as poverty and inequality. 

Benigno Aquino III passed away on June 24, 2021, due to renal disease and diabetes.  His death was widely mourned in the country, and he was praised for his integrity and commitment to democracy in the Philippines.
Tr\u01b0\u01a1ng T\u1ea5n Sang:
Trương Tấn Sang is a Vietnamese politician who held high government positions, including that of President of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam from 2011 to 2016. 

Born on January 21, 1949 in the province of My Tho, which is now part of Tiền Giang province in southern Vietnam, Trương Tấn Sang joined the Communist Party of Vietnam at a young age and climbed the ranks of Vietnamese politics over the years. 

Sang pursued higher education at the Nguyễn Ái Quốc School of Politics, primarily aimed at training party cadres.  At the beginning of his political career, he held several positions within the party and local administration, including in the Party Committee of Ho Chi Minh City. 

In the 1990s and early 2000s, Sang continued to rise in the hierarchy of the CPV, assuming increasingly important roles.  He was appointed to the Politburo of the Communist Party of Vietnam, which is the country's supreme political decision-making body, and became an influential figure within the Vietnamese government. 

Trương Tấn Sang was elected President of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam at the 11th National Congress of the Communist Party of Vietnam in January 2011, succeeding Nguyễn Minh Triết.  As president, Sang held a primarily ceremonial position, as Vietnam is a one-party state where real power is held by the CPV General Secretary, the Prime Minister, and the Party's Politburo.  However, as head of state, Sang represented Vietnam on the international stage and played an important role in conducting diplomacy and signing international agreements. 

During his presidency, Sang worked to strengthen ties with neighboring countries and international partners, promote economic growth, and maintain social stability in Vietnam.  Although his role was mainly symbolic, he was involved in initiatives to promote modernization and economic integration of Vietnam into the world. 

After completing his term in 2016, Sang was succeeded by Trần Đại Quang as President.  Details about Sang's post-presidential life and activities are relatively limited, as is often the case for former CPV leaders who generally retreat from public life after their service. 

Due to the nature of the Vietnamese political regime and the secrecy surrounding the lives of party personalities, the available information may be less detailed or accessible compared to political figures in more open systems.
Recep Tayyip Erdo\u011fan:
Recep Tayyip Erdoğan is a Turkish politician who has been serving as the President of Turkey since 2014.  Before becoming president, he also served as the Prime Minister of the country from 2003 to 2014 and was the Mayor of Istanbul from 1994 to 1998.  As a founding member of the Justice and Development Party (AKP), Erdoğan has been a central figure in Turkish politics since the 1990s. 

Born on February 26, 1954, in Istanbul, Erdoğan grew up in a modest neighborhood of the city.  He studied at the Istanbul School of Business but was influenced by politics from a young age.  He became involved in Islamist and nationalist movements in Turkey, which at the time were in opposition to the strict secularism imposed by the Kemalist legacy. 

He was first elected Mayor of Istanbul in 1994 under the banner of the Welfare Party (RP), an Islamist party.  His term as mayor was marked by effective reforms in municipal services, but in 1998, after he recited a poem considered to incite religious hatred, he was sentenced to prison, which forced him to resign from his position as mayor. 

Upon his release from prison, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan and other reformist members of the dissolved RP founded the AKP in 2001, a party that sought to present itself as pro-European, democratic, and moderately Islamist, seeking a synthesis between traditional Turkish values and modernization. 

In 2002, the Justice and Development Party (AKP) won a landslide victory in the elections, allowing Erdoğan to become Prime Minister in 2003, after a change in legislation lifted the ban that had been imposed on him due to his previous conviction. 

During his term as Prime Minister, Turkey experienced significant economic growth while beginning accession negotiations with the European Union.  The reforms carried out by his government were praised for modernizing the Turkish economy, but his tenure was also marked by an increasingly authoritarian approach, especially after 2011, raising criticisms and concerns regarding human rights and press freedom. 

In 2014, Erdoğan was elected President of Turkey, subsequently introducing constitutional changes that expanded the powers of the presidency.  These changes were approved in a referendum in 2017, transforming Turkey from a parliamentary system to an executive presidential system. 

President Erdoğan is a divisive figure: some praise him for bringing stability and economic growth, while others criticize him for his authoritarian style of governance and policies that they believe undermine the democratic and secular principles of the Turkish Republic.  His role in regional policies, his management of the Kurdish issue, responses to coups and political crises, while refining his position on the international stage, continue to shape his legacy as a dominant figure in contemporary Turkish history.
Hassan Rouhani:
Hassan Rouhani is an Iranian politician who served as the President of Iran from 2013 to 2021.  He was born on November 12, 1948 in Sorkheh, near Semnan, Iran.  Trained in law and holding a PhD in constitutional law from the University of Glasgow, Rouhani also received religious education and holds the title of Hodjatoleslam, a clerical rank in the Iranian Shia system, indicating an advanced level of study in Islam, without reaching the highest rank of Ayatollah. 

Rouhani started to gain recognition during the Iranian Revolution of 1979, where he was close to Ayatollah Khomeini, the founder of the Islamic Republic of Iran.  After the revolution, he held several important positions within the government, including as a member of parliament (Majles), a member of the Supreme National Security Council, deputy commander-in-chief of the armed forces during the Iran-Iraq war, and secretary of the Supreme National Security Council. 

As secretary of the Supreme National Security Council from 1989 to 2005, Rouhani played a significant role in Iran's defense and security policy, including the Iranian nuclear program.  He also served as Iran's chief nuclear negotiator from 2003 to 2005, working to ease tensions with the West. 

Elected president in June 2013, he took office on August 3, 2013, succeeding Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.  With a speech perceived as moderate compared to conservative figures in Iran, Rouhani focused his policy on economic and diplomatic reform.  His administration was marked by the signing of the 2015 Iran nuclear deal, known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), in which Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program in exchange for the lifting of international sanctions. 

However, in 2018, the unilateral withdrawal of the United States from the agreement under the presidency of Donald Trump and the reimposition of severe sanctions dealt a serious blow to Rouhani's strategy and increased international tensions, as well as economic difficulties in Iran. 

At the end of his second term in August 2021, he was succeeded by Ebrahim Raisi, a conservative chief justice, after an election marked by low turnout and the absence of major reformist candidates. 

Beyond his political career, Rouhani has also written several books on political, religious, and legal subjects.  His career reflects the complex balance between reformist and conservative ideologies in Iran and the struggle to maintain Iranian influence on the international stage while managing internal and external pressures around issues such as human rights and the nuclear program.
Prayut Chan-o-cha:
Prayut Chan-o-cha is a Thai politician and army general born on March 21, 1954, in Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand.  He is known for being the Prime Minister of Thailand, a position he has held since the military coup in May 2014. 

Military Career:
Prayut began his military career after graduating from the Royal Military Academy of Chulachomklao in 1972.  He rose through the ranks in the Royal Thai Army, where he held several key positions before becoming the army chief in 2010.  During his military career, he was recognized for his expertise in security issues and his involvement in operations against insurgents in southern Thailand. 

2014 Coup:
On May 22, 2014, after declaring martial law and holding talks between the country's different political factions that did not result in an agreement, Prayut led a coup that overthrew the elected government of Yingluck Shinawatra.  The coup was carried out by the National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO), a military junta led by Prayut.  As the head of the NCPO, Prayut became the de facto leader of Thailand. 

Prime Minister:
Shortly after the coup, Prayut was appointed Prime Minister by an unelected parliament and promised to restore order and lead the country towards democracy.  However, his government faced criticism for its authoritarian practices, media censorship, and repression of civil liberties. 

Under Prayut's leadership, the Thai government drafted a new constitution, adopted by referendum in 2016, which was seen as favoring the maintenance of military influence in Thai politics.  In March 2019, new general elections were held, the first since the 2014 coup.  The pro-Prayut party, Palang Pracharath, emerged as one of the main forces in the new parliament, and Prayut was re-elected as Prime Minister. 

Criticism and Support:
Prayut has been a controversial figure both nationally and internationally.  His critics see him as an authoritarian leader who has used military power to undermine democracy in Thailand.  His supporters, however, believe that he has brought some stability to a country long plagued by political turmoil. 

Throughout his political career, Prayut has sought to promote what he considers national discipline and economic development, while facing challenges such as the COVID-19 crisis and its economic repercussions. 

Beyond his role in politics, Prayut is married and has two children.  He is also known to have elicited reactions with his sometimes direct and even blunt public statements, which have contributed to his image as a frank and decisive personality. 

It is important to note that the information above represents the state of affairs up to my last point of knowledge in 2023 and that the circumstances or positions of Prayut Chan-o-cha may change over time.
Thein Sein:
Thein Sein is a Burmese politician who served as President of the Republic of the Union of Myanmar (also known as Burma) from 2011 to 2016.  He was born on April 20, 1945 in the Kyonku district within the Irrawaddy region. 

Before becoming president, Thein Sein had a long and distinguished career in the Burmese military.  He joined the army in 1968 after completing his studies at the Defence Services Academy.  He rose through the ranks within the military hierarchy, serving in various regions of the country and holding various key positions. 

Thein Sein became a significant political figure when he was appointed to the government as Prime Minister in the cabinet of the former military junta leader, General Than Shwe.  He served in this role from 2007 until 2011.  During his tenure as Prime Minister, Thein Sein was perceived as a relatively modest and consensus-seeking figure compared to other more hardline military leaders. 

After leaving the military, Thein Sein entered politics as a civilian.  He was elected president in 2011 following the general elections in 2010, which took place after nearly five decades of direct military rule in Burma.  Although these elections were widely criticized by international observers for their lack of transparency and fairness, they marked an important step in the country's transition to a civilian government. 

As president, Thein Sein undertook several reforms, including the release of many political prisoners, relaxations in media censorship, and openings for more political dialogue.  His presidency saw the resumption of international relations with Western countries, including the lifting of many economic sanctions imposed on the previous military regime. 

Progress was made under his governance in terms of national reconciliation, including peace talks with armed ethnic groups.  However, his tenure was also marked by criticism regarding the slow pace of reforms and the management of ethnic and religious conflicts, particularly violence against the Rohingya Muslim community. 

In 2015, with elections resulting in the victory of the party of the former opposition leader and Nobel Peace Prize laureate, Aung San Suu Kyi, power was peacefully transferred.  Thein Sein played a role in this peaceful transition of power, earning him praise from the international community.  After the end of his term, he largely retired from active political life. 

Thein Sein remains an important figure in contemporary Burmese history for his role in the transition process from an autocratic military regime to an increasingly civil and open government.
Park Geun-hye:
Park Geun-hye is a South Korean politician, born on February 2, 1952 in Daegu.  She is the eldest daughter of the third South Korean president, Park Chung-hee, who ruled the country from 1963 to 1979.  Her mother, Yuk Young-soo, was assassinated in 1974 by a North Korean sympathizer in an assassination attempt targeting her father.  After her mother's death, Park Geun-hye, then 22 years old, assumed the role of first lady of South Korea alongside her father until he was assassinated in 1979 by his own intelligence chief. 

Park Geun-hye studied electronics at Sogang University in Seoul and also obtained a degree in electronic engineering from the University of Grenoble Alpes in France. 

Her political career truly began in 1998 when she was first elected as a member of parliament under the Grand National Party (GNP) label, which later became the Saenuri Party.  She quickly became a prominent figure in South Korean politics.  She led the GNP from 2004 to 2006 and again from 2011 to 2012. 

In 2012, Park Geun-hye was elected the 11th President of the Republic of Korea, becoming the first woman to hold the presidency of the country.  Her political agenda included promoting the creative economy and taking a firmer stance towards North Korea, while also fostering efforts to strengthen inter-Korean cooperation and exchanges. 

However, her presidency was marred by a series of corruption scandals and abuses of power, culminating in accusations that she allowed a close confidante, Choi Soon-sil, to interfere in government affairs and extort funds from South Korean companies.  These revelations sparked mass protests in late 2016, leading to Park Geun-hye's impeachment process in December of the same year. 

The South Korean Constitutional Court confirmed her impeachment in March 2017, officially removing her from the presidency.  Park was arrested shortly after and charged with multiple crimes, including corruption, coercion, and abuse of power.  She was sentenced to several decades in prison, but has consistently denied the allegations against her. 

Park Geun-hye's removal from power had a significant impact on South Korean politics, renewing calls for political and judicial reform and highlighting issues of corruption and collusion between political elites and major companies in the country.
Fuad Masum:
Mohammed Fuad Masoum, born on January 1, 1938 in Koya, in Iraqi Kurdistan, is an Iraqi politician of Kurdish origin.  He is the seventh President of Iraq, having served from July 24, 2014, to October 2, 2018.  Masoum was one of the founders of the Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP), one of the main Kurdish political parties in Iraq. 

Fuad Masoum comes from a family with a long history of fighting for Kurdish rights.  He pursued higher education in law and Sharia at the University of Baghdad before continuing his studies at al-Azhar University in Cairo, where he obtained a doctorate in Islamic philosophy. 

During the 1960s, he played an active role in Kurdish political movements.  His political commitment began significantly when he joined the Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP) in 1964.  Under the Ba'athist regime hostile to the Kurds, he was forced into exile several times. 

Masoum spent much of his life in exile, mainly in Iran and Syria, but also briefly in Great Britain.  During his exile, he continued to be involved in Kurdish and Iraqi affairs, participating in negotiations and peace initiatives. 

After the fall of Saddam Hussein in 2003 and the establishment of a new Iraqi government, Masoum returned to Iraq and was elected to the new National Assembly as a member of the KDP.  Between 2005 and 2013, he served as Vice President of the Iraqi National Assembly and later as President of the Iraqi Council of Representatives. 

On July 24, 2014, Fuad Masoum was elected President of Iraq by the Iraqi Parliament.  His term was marked by his attempt to navigate the sectarian and ethnic tensions in the country, while facing the emergence of the Islamic State (IS) and the war efforts against this terrorist group.  He is also recognized for promoting dialogue and national reconciliation, and for his efforts in establishing a federal governance that fairly includes the different components of Iraqi society. 

After serving a single term as president, Masoum was not re-elected for a second term.  Following his presidential term, he continued to be an influential voice in Iraq, offering his wisdom and experience within the current political movements. 

Fuad Masoum is known for being a moderate and conciliatory figure, having cordial relationships across the wide spectrum of Iraqi politics, including between Arabs and Kurds, as well as Sunnis and Shiites, enabling him to play an important role in the complex and often divided Iraqi politics.
Ashraf Ghani:
Ashraf Ghani is an Afghan economist and politician who served as the President of Afghanistan from September 29, 2014, to August 15, 2021, when he fled the country following the Taliban's takeover of Kabul. 

Born on May 12, 1949, in Logar, Ashraf Ghani grew up in Afghanistan.  He pursued higher education in the United States, obtaining a Bachelor's and a Master's degree in Anthropology from the American University of Beirut.  He later earned a Ph. D.  from the prestigious Columbia University. 

After his studies, Ashraf Ghani joined the World Bank as an anthropologist and economist, working on projects aimed at improving living conditions in developing countries.  During his time at the World Bank and through other international institutions, Ghani gained a reputation as an effective technocrat and was involved in post-conflict reconstruction in several countries. 

Following the events of September 11, 2001, and the subsequent fall of the Taliban in Afghanistan, Ghani returned to his homeland to participate in the reconstruction efforts.  He held various high-level positions, including serving as a finance advisor to interim President Hamid Karzai, and later becoming the Chancellor of Kabul University. 

In 2009, Ghani entered politics by running for the presidential election, although he did not gain significant traction.  However, in his second attempt in 2014, he won the controversial presidential election, marked by allegations of fraud that required a UN-supervised audit.  Eventually, Ghani took office after reaching a power-sharing agreement with his rival Abdullah Abdullah. 

During his tenure, he focused on improving security, strengthening the economy, combating corruption, and reconciling with the Taliban.  Despite peace efforts, armed conflicts continued, and the Taliban maintained a strong presence in various parts of the country. 

Ghani's second term began in 2019 after another controversial election.  Peace talks between the United States, the Taliban, and the Afghan government intensified, but no notable success was achieved in reaching a lasting agreement. 

Afghanistan's security situation deteriorated rapidly after the withdrawal of US and NATO forces in 2021.  The Taliban launched a swift offensive that led to the fall of Kabul on August 15, 2021.  Ghani left Afghanistan as the Taliban entered the city, a decision he later justified as an attempt to avoid bloodshed. 

Ghani's departure was widely criticized both within the Afghan population and by the international community, and his legacy remains controversial.  After resigning, Ghani went into exile in the United Arab Emirates.  Since then, he has defended his actions as president and stated that his departure was aimed at preventing a greater tragedy.
Salman of Saudi Arabia:
Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud is the King of Saudi Arabia, a prominent head of state in the Middle East, and the custodian of Islam's two holiest mosques.  Born on December 31, 1935, he is the son of the founder of Saudi Arabia, Ibn Saud, and his sixth wife, Hassa bint Ahmed al Sudairi.  Salman is his father's 25th son. 

His youth was marked by traditional Saudi education, where he became familiar with religion, science, Arabic literature, as well as learning from the kingdom's governments and administrators. 

Salman began his political career by becoming the governor of Riyadh in 1954 at the age of 19, a position he held for nearly five decades.  During this time, he was credited with transforming Riyadh from a modest city into a modern metropolis.  His administration was also known for economic reforms and infrastructure projects that contributed to the capital's development. 

In 2011, after the death of his brother Nayef, Salman was appointed Minister of Defense.  In this role, he oversaw the Saudi armed forces and was responsible for significant arms acquisitions to enhance the kingdom's military power. 

Following the death of King Abdullah in January 2015, Salman ascended to the throne at the age of 79.  His reign has been marked by several significant changes both domestically and internationally, including ambitious economic reforms under Vision 2030, a plan aimed at reducing the country's reliance on oil revenues and diversifying its economy. 

On the international stage, he has managed often complex relationships with Western allies, particularly the United States, and has led a coalition of Arab countries in the conflict in Yemen, a controversial military intervention launched in 2015. 

Despite facing several health issues over the years, Salman continues to lead the kingdom, often relying on Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman (MBS), his son, who has taken on an increasingly central role in governing the country, including cracking down on dissent and implementing social reforms such as granting women the right to drive. 

Under Salman, politics is a balancing act between maintaining Saudi Arabia's traditions and conservative values while trying to modernize and diversify the economy.  However, his reign has also been criticized in terms of human rights, particularly following the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi in 2018, a crime for which Saudi agents were held responsible, tarnishing the kingdom's image. 

As of the writing of this text, Salman continues to rule, although international attention is increasingly focused on Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman as a rising figure in Saudi politics and a possible future king.
Islam Karimov:
Islam Abduganiyevich Karimov was an Uzbek statesman who was the first president of independent Uzbekistan, from its independence in 1991 until his death in 2016.  He was born on January 30, 1938 in Samarkand, then part of the Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic (Uzbek SSR) within the Soviet Union.  Karimov grew up in an orphanage before being raised by adoptive parents. 

Karimov first studied at the Tashkent Polytechnic Institute where he received a degree in mechanical engineering, and then at the Tashkent Institute of Economics, where he studied economics.  After graduating, he worked in various industries and held several managerial positions in the Soviet economic apparatus of Uzbekistan. 

He began his political career as a member of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (CPSU), rising through the ranks to become the leader of the Party in Uzbekistan in 1989.  When the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991, Karimov was well positioned to take control of the new independent state of Uzbekistan.  He was elected president of Uzbekistan in the republic's first presidential elections in December 1991, and was sworn in on March 24, 1992. 

Karimov was known for his authoritarian regime.  Under his leadership, Uzbekistan was criticized for its human rights violations, including torture, arbitrary detentions, and repression of civil liberties.  His economic policy was based on strict state control, although there were some attempts at economic reforms and attracting foreign investments. 

Internationally, he pursued a policy of non-alignment, cooperating with both Western powers such as the United States and the European Union, as well as with Russia and China, while keeping some distance from each.  After the September 11, 2001 attacks, he allowed the U. S.  military to use the Karshi-Khanabad air base for operations in Afghanistan, although this cooperation was later suspended. 

Karimov was re-elected president several times, often with overwhelming official support, although the elections were widely viewed as not free and fair by international observers.  His longevity in power made him one of the most enduring leaders in the post-Soviet region. 

Islam Karimov passed away on September 2, 2016, after suffering a brain hemorrhage.  His death marked the end of an era in Uzbekistan and opened a period of transition and potential political renewal in the country.  He was succeeded by Shavkat Mirziyoyev, who launched a series of reforms to open up the economy and improve foreign relations while maintaining firm political control.
Najib Razak:
Najib Razak, whose full name is Dato' Sri Haji Mohammad Najib bin Tun Haji Abdul Razak, is a Malaysian politician born on July 23, 1953 in Kuala Lipis, Pahang, Malaysia.  He served as the Prime Minister of Malaysia from 2009 to 2018.  Coming from an influential political family, his father, Abdul Razak Hussein, also served as the Prime Minister of Malaysia, and his uncle, Hussein Onn, held the same position. 

Biography:

Youth and Education:
Najib was born into the Malaysian political aristocracy and was educated at prestigious institutions both in Malaysia and abroad.  He graduated from the University of Nottingham in the United Kingdom with a bachelor's degree in industrial economics. 

Early Political Career:
He entered politics shortly after his father's sudden death in 1976, winning the by-election for the parliamentary constituency of Pekan, which his father had represented.  He then became the youngest Member of Parliament to be elected in Malaysia at the age of 23. 

Political Ascension:
Najib climbed the ranks of the UMNO (United Malays National Organisation) political party, which is the main party of the ruling coalition Barisan Nasional (National Front) in Malaysia since the country's independence.  He held various ministerial positions, including Defense and Education. 

Prime Minister of Malaysia:
On April 3, 2009, Najib Razak succeeded Abdullah Ahmad Badawi as the Prime Minister.  Under his leadership, the government implemented economic reforms and liberal policies aimed at modernizing the country.  One of his significant projects was the Economic Transformation Programme aimed at turning Malaysia into a high-income economy. 

Controversies and Scandals:
Najib's career was marred by various scandals, the most significant being the controversy surrounding the public investment fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB).  Allegations of massive corruption involving billions of dollars diverted from the fund and money laundering charges marked the end of his political career.  These scandals contributed to his party's electoral defeat in 2018, followed by Najib's arrest and trial for corruption. 

Personal Life:
Najib Razak is married to Rosmah Mansor, who has also been implicated in allegations of corruption and extravagant spending.  He is the father of five children. 

It is important to note that this biography summarizes Najib Razak's career up to my last update in 2023.  Events after this date are not taken into account in this summary.
Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi:
Abdrabbuh Mansour Hadi is a Yemeni politician born on September 1, 1945 in the region of Abyan in Yemen.  He served as the President of Yemen from 2012 to 2022, succeeding Ali Abdullah Saleh during the Arab Spring and as part of a political transition negotiated by the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC), but his authority was contested by the Houthi rebels. 

Hadi began his military career in the army of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen (South Yemen), a Marxist nation before its unification with North Yemen in 1990.  He was trained in British and Soviet military establishments and rose through the ranks to become a senior officer in the Yemeni army. 

After the unification of Yemen, Hadi continued his career as a military and politician, holding various positions including Minister of Defense.  In 1994, he played a major role in the civil war that pitted the north against the south of Yemen, which had been militarily unified only four years earlier. 

In 1994, following the civil war, Hadi became the Vice President under the presidency of Ali Abdullah Saleh.  He served in this position for nearly two decades.  During his tenure as Vice President, he was considered a rather subdued figure, often overshadowed by Saleh's strong personality. 

The political situation in Yemen drastically changed in 2011 when a series of protests, inspired by the Arab Spring, erupted throughout the country, demanding an end to Saleh's long-standing rule.  Faced with national and international pressure, Saleh eventually agreed to sign an agreement negotiated by the GCC countries, agreeing to transfer power to Hadi. 

Hadi assumed the interim presidency on November 23, 2011, and was formally elected President for a two-year transition period in a presidential election in February 2012, where he was the sole candidate.  His presidency was meant to pave the way for a new constitution and broader political reforms.  However, the transition period was marked by increasing political instability, armed conflicts, and the rise in power of the Houthi rebels, a Zaidi Shia group from northern Yemen. 

In September 2014, the Houthis took control of the capital, Sanaa, and in January 2015, placed Hadi under house arrest.  He managed to escape to Aden in February 2015, where he rescinded his earlier resignation and declared that he remained the legitimate president of Yemen.  In March 2015, the Houthis advanced towards Aden, forcing Hadi to flee to Saudi Arabia. 

The Saudi-led military intervention began in March 2015, in support of Hadi and his government against the Houthis.  Since then, Yemen has been plunged into a devastating civil war, leading to a severe humanitarian crisis. 

Although Hadi is still internationally recognized as the legitimate president of Yemen for much of the civil war, his exiled government has struggled to exert its authority in the face of different factions and the multiple security challenges affecting the country.  In April 2022, Hadi transferred his powers to a new presidential council in an attempt to consolidate unity against the Houthis and revitalize the political process. 

Hadi's presidency has been marred by accusations of corruption and an inability to establish stability and peace in a deeply divided Yemen.  Power struggles between rival factions, the presence of AQAP (Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula), attacks by the Houthis, the humanitarian crisis, and the cholera epidemic are among the challenges that Hadi and Yemen have been unable to overcome.
Sushil Koirala:
Sushil Koirala was a Nepalese politician who served as the Prime Minister of Nepal.  He was born on August 12, 1939 in Biratnagar, Nepal, into an influential political family; the Koirala family has played a significant role in Nepalese politics, with several members being involved in leadership positions. 

Sushil Koirala entered politics at a young age by getting involved in the Nepali Congress, a Nepalese social-democratic political party.  He became a party member in 1954 and quickly rose through the ranks to become one of its most respected leaders.  Koirala was primarily known for his role in the struggle for democracy in Nepal, especially during the years when Nepal was under authoritarian rule. 

In the 1990s, when Nepal transitioned to a multi-party democracy, Sushil Koirala played a key role in establishing new democratic institutions in the country.  He also served multiple times as a member of the Nepalese House of Representatives. 

Sushil Koirala is mainly recognized for being elected as the Prime Minister of Nepal on February 10, 2014.  His tenure was marked by several major challenges, including the process of drafting a new constitution for Nepal.  He led efforts for the new constitution to be adopted, which eventually occurred in September 2015, a significant milestone for the consolidation of Nepalese democracy. 

However, his tenure was also marked by a major natural disaster, the devastating earthquake that struck Nepal in April 2015, killing nearly 9,000 people and causing massive damage.  His handling of the earthquake aftermath was criticized, with many faulting him for a lack of effectiveness and speed in responding to the needs of the victims. 

Koirala was known for his austere and simple lifestyle and was considered a man of integrity.  Despite hailing from a powerful political family, he maintained a reputation for moderation and honesty throughout his career. 

Sushil Koirala passed away on February 9, 2016 at the age of 76.  Despite the controversies and challenges during his tenure as Prime Minister, he remains a respected figure in Nepalese political history, lauded for his commitment to democracy and national interest.
Vladimir Putin:
Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin is a Russian statesman born on October 7, 1952 in Leningrad, now Saint Petersburg.  He is known for being the dominant leader of Russia since the late 1990s, having served as both president and prime minister of the country. 

Putin grew up in Leningrad in a working-class family.  After studying law at Leningrad State University, he joined the KGB, the Soviet intelligence service, in 1975.  He had a 16-year career there, mainly in East Germany. 

After the fall of the Soviet Union, Putin returned to Leningrad and entered politics under the tutelage of the reformist mayor Anatoly Sobchak.  In 1996, he was called to Moscow by President Boris Yeltsin and held various increasingly important administrative positions, eventually becoming head of the Federal Security Service (FSB), successor to the KGB. 

In 1999, Putin was appointed prime minister by Yeltsin, who resigned shortly thereafter, allowing Putin to become interim president on December 31, 1999.  He was officially elected president in 2000, and re-elected in 2004.  His first term was marked by economic reforms and a recentralization of power.  Conflicts in Chechnya, as well as his handling of the hostage crisis at a Moscow theater in 2002 and at the Beslan school in 2004, highlighted his sometimes brutal methods and ruthless approach to terrorism. 

Due to constitutional limits, Putin could not run for a third consecutive term in 2008.  He orchestrated the election of his protégé, Dmitry Medvedev, and became prime minister, while remaining the dominant figure in the duo.  In 2012, after a change in the constitution extending presidential terms from four to six years, Putin was re-elected president. 

Putin's policy is characterized by his nationalism, control over the media, repression of the opposition, and assertive geopolitical position.  His time in power has seen the annexation of Crimea in 2014, the Russian military intervention in Syria in 2015, and involvement in various regional and international conflicts.  His handling of domestic and foreign affairs has led to tensions with Western countries, particularly due to allegations of interference in foreign elections and support for authoritarian regimes. 

Putin's popularity in Russia is often attributed to the relative stability after the chaotic years following the fall of the USSR, as well as the reappropriation of natural resources that has boosted economic growth.  However, his regime is criticized for widespread corruption, deterioration of democratic standards, and decline of civil liberties. 

In 2020, constitutional reforms were approved through a national referendum, potentially allowing Putin to remain in power until 2036 if re-elected.  His policies, longevity in power, and means of maintaining order evoke as much admiration as controversy on the international stage.
Joachim Gauck:
Joachim Gauck is a German politician and Lutheran pastor born on January 24, 1940 in Rostock.  He is mainly known for having been the President of the Federal Republic of Germany from 2012 to 2017. 

Before becoming president, Gauck played a key role in the democratic movement in East Germany (GDR), which contributed to the fall of the Berlin Wall and the subsequent reunification of Germany.  As a pastor, he was an active member of the Protestant Church, which provided a space for public debate and dissent in a society otherwise dominated by state surveillance. 

In the 1980s, Gauck became increasingly involved in the civil rights movements in the GDR.  He played a role in the creation of the "Neues Forum," a political movement that called for the democratization of the communist regime. 

After the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 and the dissolution of the GDR, Joachim Gauck was appointed to lead the authority responsible for the Stasi archives, the East German secret police.  As the Federal Commissioner for the Stasi Records from 1990 to 2000, he oversaw the review and release of files of millions of East Germans monitored by the Stasi. 

Joachim Gauck is not affiliated with any political party, although he is considered to have liberal and conservative views.  He was supported by Angela Merkel's conservative coalition as well as by the Social Democrats and the Greens when he was elected President of Germany in March 2012. 

As president, a mainly ceremonial role in Germany, Gauck advocated for the values of freedom, democracy, and responsibility.  He spoke out on important issues such as immigrant integration, the euro crisis, and Germany's role in international affairs.  During his term, he played a role in strengthening national unity and encouraging dialogue between different parts of society. 

He decided not to seek a second term for reasons of age and health.  After leaving his presidential duties in 2017, he continued to participate in public debates and initiatives promoting democracy and human rights. 

The life of Joachim Gauck reflects Germany's history over the past half century, including the division and reunification of Germany, the struggle for democracy in former East Germany, and Germany's role in Europe after reunification.
David Cameron:
David Cameron is a British politician who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 2010 to 2016.  He was born on October 9, 1966, in London. 

Cameron grew up in Berkshire and attended Eton College, one of the most prestigious independent schools in the UK.  He then studied Philosophy, Politics, and Economics (PPE) at the University of Oxford, where he graduated with honors in 1988. 

He began his professional career with the Conservatives, working in the Conservative Party research department before becoming a special adviser in John Major's government.  Before returning to politics, Cameron worked for four years as Director of Communications for Carlton Communications, a British media company. 

Cameron was elected as the Member of Parliament for the Witney constituency in Oxfordshire in 2001 and became the leader of the Conservative Party in 2005.  As opposition leader, he sought to modernize the party, moving away from some of the harsher political positions and emphasizing issues such as climate change and social inclusion. 

In 2010, after the general elections, no party won an absolute majority, and Cameron became Prime Minister leading a coalition government between the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats led by Nick Clegg.  This was the first British coalition since World War II. 

As Prime Minister, Cameron implemented a series of reforms in economic, social, and foreign policy.  He pursued an austerity policy to reduce the national deficit, which was both praised for stabilizing the economy and criticized for exacerbating inequalities. 

One of the most significant moments of his tenure was managing the referendum on Scottish independence in 2014, where he successfully campaigned for Scotland to remain part of the UK. 

However, he may be best known internationally for organizing the 2016 referendum on the UK's membership in the European Union, a promise he had made to appease the eurosceptic faction of his party.  Against his own wishes, the referendum resulted in a vote for Brexit, and Cameron announced his resignation the day after the announcement of the results, believing he could not be the leader to lead the EU exit negotiations. 

After leaving 10 Downing Street, Cameron retired from politics and has since worked as a speaker and in business.  His time as Prime Minister remains controversial, especially due to the economic and political consequences of Brexit.
Fran\u00e7ois Hollande:
François Hollande, born on August 12, 1954 in Rouen, Seine-Maritime, is a French statesman.  A member of the Socialist Party (PS), he held the position of President of the French Republic from May 15, 2012 to May 14, 2017. 

Hollande grew up in a middle-class family and attended Pasteur High School in Neuilly-sur-Seine.  He studied at the Paris Institute of Political Studies (Sciences Po) before entering the Paris Institute of Political Studies (HEC), and then the National School of Administration (ENA) from which he graduated in the Voltaire promotion, a class that includes several personalities who have marked French political life, including his former partner Ségolène Royal. 

During his youth, he became involved in activism within the Socialist Party.  After graduating from ENA in 1980, he worked as an economic advisor at the Court of Audit and also became a special advisor to President François Mitterrand. 

Hollande's political career took off in the 1980s.  He was elected as a deputy for Corrèze in 1988 and became the first secretary of the Socialist Party in 1997, a position he held until 2008.  His management of the party experienced highs and lows, notably due to the mixed results of the PS in elections and internal tensions. 

In 2011, François Hollande won the Socialist Party's citizen primary for the 2012 presidential election.  Advocating a "normal" and accessible style, contrasting with Nicolas Sarkozy's presidency, he was elected as the 24th President of the French Republic on May 6, 2012, defeating the incumbent president. 

During his presidential term, Hollande faced several challenges: the economic and financial crisis, high unemployment, military intervention in Mali (Operation Serval) and the Central African Republic, as well as terrorist attacks on French soil in 2015, including the Charlie Hebdo attacks in January and the Paris attacks in November. 

Economically, he launched the Responsibility and Solidarity Pact to boost employment and growth.  However, several of his measures, including the Labor Law carried by his minister Myriam El Khomri, sparked significant social unrest and divisions within his majority. 

His popularity rating fluctuated during his term.  Although respected on the international stage, especially for his crisis management, his presidency was often criticized in France for its lack of clear direction and perceived inadequate economic results. 

After considering running for a second term, Hollande announced on December 1, 2016 that he would not seek re-election, a first for an incumbent president under the Fifth Republic.  His term ended in May 2017, and he was succeeded by Emmanuel Macron. 

After the end of his presidency, he stepped away from active politics but remains an influential figure in the Socialist Party and a regular commentator on public affairs.  He shares his thoughts and analyses in several works, including a memoir titled "Lessons of Power" released in 2018, where he reflects on his journey and presidency.
Sergio Mattarella:
Sergio Mattarella is an Italian politician and jurist born on July 23, 1941 in Palermo, Sicily.  He was elected as the 12th President of the Italian Republic on January 31, 2015, and took the oath of office on February 3, 2015.  His term was marked by a period of political turbulence and several government crises. 

Coming from a politically engaged family, his father, Bernardo Mattarella, was an anti-fascist and a historical leader of the Christian Democracy (Democrazia Cristiana, DC), a dominant party in Italian politics from the post-war period until the 1990s.  His brother, Piersanti Mattarella, was the President of the Sicily region before being assassinated by the mafia in 1980, an event that deeply affected Sergio and his commitment against organized crime. 

Sergio Mattarella began his career as a professor of parliamentary law at the University of Palermo before entering politics.  Elected as a deputy for the DC in 1983, he held several ministerial positions in the 1980s and 1990s.  He notably served as Minister for Relations with Parliament, Minister of Education, and Minister of Defense, making him a respected figure in Italian politics. 

Throughout his political career, Mattarella built a reputation for integrity and moderation.  He contributed to the reform of the Italian electoral system and was an advocate for constitutional rights and justice. 

After the collapse of the DC in the 1990s following the corruption scandals of the Clean Hands operation (Mani Pulite), Mattarella joined the Italian People's Party (PPI), one of the successors of the DC.  He later participated in the creation of The Daisy (La Margherita) and the Democratic Party (PD). 

A key moment in his political career before the presidency was his opposition to the Gasparri media law in 2003, which was seen as a way to strengthen media control by the then Prime Minister, Silvio Berlusconi.  In protest, Mattarella resigned from his position as a deputy. 

Before becoming president, Mattarella was elected as a judge to the Constitutional Court in 2011 by the Italian Parliament.  His election to the presidency was somewhat unexpected, but his profile as a moderate and his commitment to constitutional and republican values led to broad consensus around his candidacy. 

As president, he played an active role in resolving political crises, responsible for appointing Prime Ministers and mediating in the formation of governments.  He was also a staunch defender of Europe and Italy's role in the European Union. 

Sergio Mattarella is known for his reserve and attention to institutional principles, characteristics that have marked his approach to the presidency.  Faced with the various challenges that Italy has faced, including the COVID-19 pandemic, he embodied a figure of stability and reassurance for many Italians.
Mariano Rajoy:
Mariano Rajoy Brey is a Spanish politician, member of the Popular Party (Partido Popular - PP), who was the President of the Government of Spain from December 21, 2011, to June 2, 2018.  Rajoy was born on March 27, 1955, in Santiago de Compostela, Galicia, Spain. 

Rajoy obtained a law degree from the University of Santiago de Compostela before becoming a property registrar official.  His political career began in the 1980s.  He was elected as a deputy for Pontevedra in the Cortes Generales in 1986, a position he held for most of his political career. 

Rajoy climbed the ranks of the Popular Party and held several ministerial positions during the governments of José María Aznar.  Between 1996 and 2003, he served as Minister of Public Administrations, Education and Culture, Presidency, and Government Spokesperson.  He also served as Vice President of the government. 

After the Popular Party's defeat in the 2004 elections, Rajoy was chosen to succeed José María Aznar as the party's leader.  He led the PP in three general elections, in 2004, 2008, and finally in 2011, where he secured a decisive victory with an absolute majority of seats in the Congress of Deputies. 

His term as President of the Government was marked by a series of challenges, including the economic and financial crisis that hit Spain hard, with unemployment rates reaching record levels.  Rajoy implemented austerity measures aimed at reducing the public deficit, as well as structural reforms such as labor market reform, which drew criticism from trade unions and a segment of the population. 

Furthermore, Rajoy had to face the rise of the independence movement in Catalonia, a significant constitutional challenge for the central government.  The referendum on Catalonia's independence in 2017 and the subsequent secession attempt led to the application of Article 155 of the Spanish Constitution, which suspended Catalonia's autonomy to restore constitutional order. 

The end of his term was overshadowed by a series of corruption scandals involving the Popular Party and a tense political climate.  Rajoy was eventually ousted by a motion of censure led by the socialist Pedro Sánchez in June 2018.  This motion of censure followed the verdict in the Gürtel case, a major corruption case involving several members of the Popular Party. 

After leaving the government, Mariano Rajoy also resigned from the presidency of the Popular Party and withdrew from active political life.  He returned to his position as a property registrar after leaving politics.
Petro Poroshenko:
Petro Poroshenko is a Ukrainian businessman and politician, born on September 26, 1965 in Bilyaivka, in the Odessa Oblast, Ukraine (then part of the Soviet Union).  He is best known for having been the fifth President of Ukraine from 2014 to 2019. 

Education and Business Career:
Poroshenko studied economics at the National University of Kyiv, where he specialized in international economic relations.  He is also a graduate of the Kyiv International Commerce and Economics University.  In the late 1980s and early 1990s, amidst the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Poroshenko successfully ventured into business, starting with the sale of cocoa and gradually expanding his business to include various industries, notably candy manufacturing under the brand Roshen, earning him the nickname "Chocolate King. "

Political Engagement:
Petro Poroshenko early on engaged in politics and held various government positions.  He was first elected to the Ukrainian parliament in 1998 and served as the Chairman of the National Bank of Ukraine.  He also served as the Minister of Foreign Affairs and Minister of Trade and Economic Development in different governments. 

Presidency:
Following the popular uprising known as the Revolution of Dignity or Euromaidan from late 2013 to early 2014, which led to the impeachment of President Viktor Yanukovych, Poroshenko ran for the Ukrainian presidency.  He was elected in May 2014 with an absolute majority in the first round, promising to end the instability in Eastern Ukraine and combat the endemic corruption in the country. 

During his term, Poroshenko faced numerous challenges, including the annexation of Crimea by Russia in March 2014 and the war in Donbass, where Russian-backed separatists clashed with Ukrainian government forces.  He advocated for closer ties with the European Union and NATO while grappling with significant internal and external pressures.  Despite progress with the signing of an association agreement with the EU, his popularity suffered due to the country's economic difficulties and corruption allegations. 

Petro Poroshenko lost the presidential election to Volodymyr Zelensky in April 2019.  After his presidency, he remained active in politics, leading the opposition to his successor and continuing to advocate for Ukraine's interests on the international stage. 

Beyond politics, Poroshenko is known for his involvement in the media and ecclesiastical realms, having founded the television channel "Channel 5" and played a role in the recognition process of the independent Ukrainian Orthodox Church separate from the Moscow Patriarchate.
Andrzej Duda:
Andrzej Duda is a Polish politician born on May 16, 1972 in Krakow.  He is a member of the Law and Justice party (Prawo i Sprawiedliwość, PiS) and has been serving as the President of the Republic of Poland since August 6, 2015. 

Andrzej Duda was raised in a family with strong academic roots.  His father was a professor at the AGH University of Science and Technology in Krakow.  Andrzej Duda studied law and graduated from the Faculty of Law and Administration at the Jagiellonian University in Krakow in 1997.  Subsequently, in 2005, he obtained a PhD in law from the Institute of Law at the Polish Academy of Sciences. 

His political career began in the early 2000s.  He worked at the Office of the Committee for European Affairs, becoming an expert in European legislation.  In 2006, he was appointed Deputy Minister of Justice, a position he held until 2007.  Then, from 2008 to 2010, he served as Deputy Chief of Staff to President Lech Kaczyński. 

In 2010, Andrzej Duda became a member of the Polish Parliament (Sejm), where he sat on the Justice and Human Rights Committee.  His political profile grew, leading to his election as a Member of the European Parliament in 2014, a position he held briefly. 

On May 24, 2015, he won the presidential election by defeating the incumbent president, Bronisław Komorowski, with 51. 55% of the votes in the second round.  His electoral campaigns focused on domestic policy issues such as lowering the retirement age, increasing family benefits, and taxing large foreign banks and supermarkets. 

Andrzej Duda is also known for his conservative positions on social issues and his commitment to traditional Polish values.  His presidency has been marked by controversial judicial reforms and tensions with the European Union over the rule of law.  Despite protests and international criticism, his government has stayed the course on these reforms, considered necessary by his supporters to combat corruption and make the judiciary more effective. 

On July 12, 2020, Andrzej Duda was re-elected for a second presidential term, defeating the Mayor of Warsaw, Rafał Trzaskowski, with just over 51% of the votes. 

As president, Andrzej Duda has also sought to strengthen Poland's ties with the United States and bolster NATO presence in Eastern Europe, particularly in response to Russia's activities in the region. 

His role as president mainly revolves around representing the Polish state internationally and ensuring respect for the Constitution, although executive power in Poland is primarily held by the Prime Minister.
Klaus Iohannis:
Klaus Werner Iohannis, also known as Klaus Werner Johannis because of his German roots, is a Romanian politician who has been serving as the President of Romania since 2014.  Born on June 13, 1959 in Sibiu, a historic city in Transylvania, Klaus Iohannis comes from the Saxon minority in Romania, a German ethnic community. 

Iohannis attended the "Samuel von Brukenthal" high school in Sibiu before obtaining a degree in physics from the University of Cluj-Napoca in 1983.  He then worked as a physics teacher.  While teaching, he pursued further studies in physical education and sports as well as physics, demonstrating his commitment to education and science. 

His political career took off when he became a member of the Democratic Forum of Germans in Romania (DFDR), a political party representing the German community in Romania.  In 2000, Iohannis was elected mayor of Sibiu.  His effective management of the city garnered national and international recognition, especially when Sibiu was designated European Capital of Culture in 2007. 

In 2009, Iohannis considered running for the presidential elections, but it wasn't until 2014, under the banner of the National Liberal Party (PNL), that he won the presidential election, defeating the incumbent Prime Minister Victor Ponta.  His campaign focused on combating corruption, reforming public administration, and strengthening the rule of law. 

As president, Iohannis has been perceived as a stable and moderate leader, focused on economic and judicial reforms.  He has also worked to enhance Romania's role on the international stage, particularly within the European Union and NATO.  His term has been marked by his firm stance against attempts by the executive branch to dilute anti-corruption efforts, triggering significant protests in Romania. 

Reelected in 2019 for a second term, Klaus Iohannis continues to play a decisive role in Romanian politics, positioning himself as a guardian of his country's democratic institutions in a sometimes complex regional context.  During his administration, Romania has faced both internal challenges, such as the COVID-19-related health crisis, and foreign policy tensions, particularly regarding relations with Russia and the security situation in the Black Sea region.
Mark Rutte:
Mark Rutte is a Dutch politician born on February 14, 1967 in The Hague, Netherlands.  A member of the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD), he has been the Prime Minister of the Netherlands since October 14, 2010, making him one of the longest-serving current leaders in Europe. 

Rutte grew up in a bourgeois family with a father who was a businessman and a stay-at-home mother.  After completing his secondary education, he studied history at Leiden University, where he obtained a master's degree in 1992.  Alongside his university studies, Rutte became involved in politics by joining the VVD youth, the Liberal Youth Organization, where he held various positions. 

Before entering active politics, Rutte worked for the Unilever conglomerate in human resources, where he rose through the ranks to hold management positions.  His experience in the private sector influenced his political views, which lean towards entrepreneurship and liberal economic principles. 

In 2002, Rutte was appointed State Secretary for Social Affairs and Employment, and later, in 2004, State Secretary for Education, Culture and Science in the cabinet led by Jan Peter Balkenende.  He was elected to the House of Representatives in 2003.

Milo\u0161 Zeman:

Alexander Lukashenko:

Hailemariam Desalegn:
