Joseph Kabila:
Joseph Kabila Kabange is a Congolese politician who served as President of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) from 2001 to 2019. 

Born on June 4, 1971 in Fizi, South Kivu, in the current DRC, Joseph Kabila is the son of a rebel who later became president, Laurent-Désiré Kabila.  Joseph spent part of his youth in Tanzania and attended military schools in China.  In the early 1990s, he joined his father in the fight against the regime of Mobutu Sese Seko. 

After Laurent-Désiré Kabila took power in 1997 and Mobutu fell during the First Congo War, Joseph Kabila became a Major General in the air force.  He played an active role in the Second Congo War which began in 1998. 

On January 16, 2001, after his father's assassination, Joseph Kabila became, at the age of 29, the Head of State of the DRC.  His rapid rise to power was seen by some as a continuation of his father's regime despite his relatively limited political experience. 

As president, Joseph Kabila was credited with ending the war and restoring relative peace and stability in the country by signing peace agreements in 2002 and 2003.  He also initiated the transition process to democracy which culminated in the country's first free and transparent elections in 40 years, held in 2006, which he won. 

Re-elected in 2011 in controversial elections, his second term was marked by political tensions, allegations of corruption, human rights issues, and ongoing conflicts in eastern DRC. 

The DRC constitution limited the number of presidential terms to two, preventing Joseph Kabila from running for a third term.  However, he remained in power beyond the official end of his term in December 2016, citing delays in organizing elections.  This led to significant protests and political tensions. 

Eventually, following internal and external pressures, elections were held in December 2018, and on January 24, 2019, Félix Tshisekedi was declared the winner, ending nearly two decades of Kabila's presidency.  Since the end of his presidency, Joseph Kabila has remained an influential figure in Congolese politics, notably through his political party, the Common Front for Congo (FCC). 

Joseph Kabila's presidency was complex, and his legacy is contested; while some credit him for ending the civil war, others criticize him for failures in governance, human rights, and the country's economic development.
Jakaya Kikwete:
Jakaya Mrisho Kikwete is a Tanzanian politician who served as the 4th President of Tanzania, in office from December 21, 2005, to November 5, 2015.  Born on October 7, 1950, in the Bagamoyo district, located in the Pwani region, he grew up in one of the poorest regions of Tanzania. 

Kikwete studied economics at the University of Dar es Salaam and graduated in 1975.  He joined the Revolutionary Party of Tanzania, Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM), immediately after completing his university studies and began his political career as an officer in the Ministry of Finance. 

His political career continued to flourish in the following years.  He held several ministerial positions, including Minister of Water, Energy, and Minerals from 1988 to 1990, Minister of Finance from 1994 to 1995, and Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1995 to 2005.  In his role as Minister of Foreign Affairs, he was recognized for his diplomatic work and efforts to promote peace in the Great Lakes region of Africa. 

In 2005, Kikwete ran for the presidency of Tanzania under the CCM banner and won with a large majority, becoming president.  During his term, he focused on promoting the Tanzanian economy, fighting corruption, improving healthcare and education systems, and consolidating national unity.  He promoted tourism in Tanzania and worked to increase foreign investments. 

On the international stage, Kikwete was very active in the African Union and other regional initiatives.  He also worked with international partners to ensure Tanzania's development and stability. 

After serving two terms, Kikwete left the presidency to John Magufuli in 2015, following the constitutional rules of Tanzania that limit the presidency to two terms.  After his presidency, Kikwete remained active in various social and diplomatic causes and served in various international leadership positions.  He continues to be a respected figure in Tanzanian and African politics.
Jacob Zuma:
Jacob Gedleyihlekisa Zuma was born on April 12, 1942 in Nkandla, in the province of KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa.  Coming from a poor and poorly educated family - his mother was a domestic worker and his father a policeman who died when he was young - Zuma did not receive a formal education and had to learn to read and write on his own. 

Here is a summarized biography of Jacob Zuma:

**Early life and activism:**
Jacob Zuma became involved in the fight against apartheid at a very young age.  At the age of 17, he joined the African National Congress (ANC), the main political party fighting for the rights of the black majority in South Africa.  In 1962, he became a member of the armed wing of the ANC, Umkhonto we Sizwe (MK), where he received military training. 

In 1963, Zuma was arrested with other ANC members and sentenced to ten years in prison for conspiracy against the apartheid government.  He spent these years imprisoned on Robben Island, the same prison where Nelson Mandela was held. 

**Political rise:**
After his release in 1973, Zuma continued his work within the ANC, spending most of his time in exile outside of South Africa.  He rose through the ranks of the ANC during the 1980s and early 1990s. 

Following Nelson Mandela's release in 1990 and the dismantling of apartheid, Zuma returned to South Africa and became a major political figure in the transition to a democratic government.  He held various high-level positions within the ANC and the South African government, including MEC (Member of the Executive Committee) for the province of KwaZulu-Natal. 

**Vice Presidency and Presidency:**
In 1999, Zuma was elected Vice President of South Africa under President Thabo Mbeki.  He became president of the ANC in 2007 after defeating Mbeki in a highly contested internal election.  Following Mbeki's dismissal by the ANC in 2008, Kgalema Motlanthe assumed the interim presidency until Zuma was elected President of South Africa in 2009. 

During his presidency, Zuma was praised for his relaxed approach and commitment to improving social welfare.  However, his tenure was marred by multiple allegations of corruption, misappropriation of public funds, and nepotism, culminating in the controversial construction of his private residence in Nkandla, which was renovated with public funds under the guise of security. 

**Downfall and consequences:**
Due to these scandals and other issues such as economic decline and public discontent, pressure mounted for Zuma to resign.  In February 2018, he yielded to the ANC's demands and resigned from his position as President of South Africa.  His Vice President, Cyril Ramaphosa, succeeded him. 

After his presidency, Zuma was formally charged with corruption and fraud related to multi-billion dollar arms deals from the 1990s.  He appeared in court several times, but his trials were marked by delays and legal challenges. 

**Legacy:**
Jacob Zuma remains a controversial figure in recent South African history.  His legacy is marked by an apparent deterioration of the integrity of government institutions and an increase in state corruption, but also by a loyal support base that views him as a champion of the people. 

It should be noted that this biography is subject to change based on legal and political developments following the information cut-off in 2023.
Uhuru Kenyatta:
Uhuru Muigai Kenyatta is a Kenyan politician who served as the 4th President of Kenya since the country's independence, holding office from April 9, 2013, to September 13, 2022.  Born on October 26, 1961, he is the eldest son of Jomo Kenyatta, the first President of Kenya, and his fourth wife, Mama Ngina Kenyatta. 

Education and Early Career:
Uhuru attended school in Nairobi at St.  Mary's School before continuing his higher education in the United States.  He studied at Amherst College in Massachusetts, where he earned a degree in Economics and Political Science.  Upon his return to Kenya, he managed several family-owned businesses involved in agriculture, banking, and tourism. 

Entry into Politics:
Kenyatta began his political career in the late 1990s.  In 1997, he lost in an election for a parliamentary seat but quickly rose through the political ranks.  He was appointed to ministerial positions by President Daniel arap Moi, including Minister of Finance. 

Political Rise:
In 2002, Moi designated Uhuru as his successor as the leader of the Kenya African National Union (KANU).  Uhuru was defeated in the 2002 presidential election by Mwai Kibaki.  Despite this loss, his political stature remained significant. 

Minister and Deputy Prime Minister:
Uhuru served in various ministerial roles under President Kibaki.  In 2007, he was elected as Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance, solidifying his position as one of the country's leading politicians. 

Presidency:
Kenyatta won the presidential election in March 2013, succeeding Mwai Kibaki.  His presidency began amidst controversy as he was accused by the International Criminal Court (ICC) of crimes against humanity for his alleged role in the 2007-2008 post-election violence.  These charges were dropped in 2014 due to lack of evidence and the disappearance of key witnesses. 

During his term, Kenyatta focused on infrastructure development, promotion of foreign investment, and expanding access to electricity in rural areas.  His policy was also marked by challenges, including terrorist attacks, allegations of corruption, and ethnic and political tensions. 

Re-election and Post-Presidency:
Uhuru Kenyatta was re-elected for a second and final term in 2017 after a controversial electoral process that involved the annulment of the initial results by the Kenyan Supreme Court, followed by a new election boycotted by the opposition. 

After stepping down from the presidency, Uhuru Kenyatta remains an influential figure in Kenyan politics and continues to play a role, possibly in a mentoring or diplomatic capacity.  His presidency is assessed in various ways by analysts and Kenyan citizens, reflecting the complexity of political, economic, and social issues that Kenya faces on the national and international stage.
Yoweri Museveni:
Yoweri Kaguta Museveni is a Ugandan statesman, born on September 15, 1944 in Ntungamo, Uganda.  He has been the President of the Republic of Uganda since 1986, after seizing power following a guerrilla war.  His political longevity makes him one of the longest-serving African leaders. 

Born in western Uganda into a pastoralist family, Museveni was educated in missionary schools before pursuing university studies in economics and political science at the University of Dar es Salaam in Tanzania.  At university, he was influenced by Pan-Africanism and leftist ideas, becoming politically active. 

In the 1970s, Museveni played a key role in the resistance against dictator Idi Amin by joining the National Resistance Front of Uganda (FRONASA).  He also supported the coup that brought Milton Obote to power in 1980.  However, when Obote was reelected in controversial elections, Museveni accused the regime of electoral fraud and launched an armed struggle. 

Museveni formed the National Resistance Army (NRA) and waged a guerrilla war against the Obote government.  After several years of conflict, and following the overthrow of Obote and a brief period of governance by Tito Okello, Museveni seized power on January 29, 1986, promising to restore peace and security. 

The early years of Museveni's presidency were marked by economic reforms aimed at stabilizing the Ugandan economy.  He encouraged free trade and the private sector, and his government implemented policies recommended by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank, leading to some degree of economic recovery. 

Politically, Museveni has been credited with relatively stabilizing Uganda after decades of unrest and civil wars, and establishing a form of democracy he called "no-party democracy", later evolving into a multi-party system in the 2000s. 

In terms of public health, his government has been recognized for successful efforts in combating the spread of HIV/AIDS in the 1990s.  Under his leadership, Uganda is often cited as a model for its awareness and prevention campaign against the epidemic. 

However, his governance is not without controversies.  During his successive terms, he has been criticized for authoritarianism, repression of political opponents, corruption, and alleged human rights violations.  Electoral processes in Uganda have often been marred by allegations of fraud and intimidation. 

Internationally, Museveni has been involved in various regional conflicts, including in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and South Sudan.  His government has been accused of supporting rebel groups in the region, although Museveni has also played a mediating role in some situations. 

Despite the Ugandan constitution initially limiting the number of presidential terms to two, amendments have been adopted, removing this limit and allowing him to run for re-election.  Museveni has been re-elected multiple times and maintains his grip on power in Uganda, despite growing opposition and calls for a democratic transfer of power.
Abdelaziz Bouteflika:
Abdelaziz Bouteflika was born on March 2, 1937 in Oujda, Morocco.  He is an Algerian statesman who served as President of the Algerian Republic from April 27, 1999 until his resignation on April 2, 2019.  His long political career was marked by several highs and lows and a controversial end. 

Bouteflika began his political career shortly after World War II, while still young.  Engaged in the struggle for Algerian independence, he joined the National Liberation Front (FLN) and quickly became an active member.  After Algeria's independence in 1962, he held several key government positions, including Minister of Youth and Sports, and then Minister of Foreign Affairs at the young age of 25, under the presidency of Ahmed Ben Bella, the first president of independent Algeria. 

As Minister of Foreign Affairs, a position he held for over a decade, Bouteflika played a significant role in strengthening Algeria's position on the international stage, supporting liberation movements in Africa and the Middle East, and contributing to mediation in various international conflicts. 

After the death of President Houari Boumédiène in 1978, with whom he had been very close, Bouteflika experienced a period of political eclipse.  He was accused of corruption and had to exile for several years, mainly in Dubai and Europe. 

He returned to Algeria in the 1990s, a period marked by the civil war between the government and Islamist armed groups.  In 1999, with the support of the Algerian army, he was elected President of the Republic.  He then implemented a policy of national reconciliation to end the conflict, including controversial amnesty measures that allowed Islamist fighters to reintegrate into society. 

Bouteflika was reelected for three additional terms in 2004, 2009, and 2014, often without real opposition and under circumstances criticized by the opposition and international observers for lacking transparency and freedom.  During his terms, he pursued economic reform policies and modernized the country's infrastructure.  Under his presidency, Algeria experienced some stability and economic growth, notably due to hydrocarbon revenues. 

However, his presidency was also characterized by increasing allegations of corruption and an increasingly autocratic power.  In 2013, Bouteflika suffered a stroke that seriously affected his health and limited his public appearances.  Nevertheless, in 2019, he announced that he would run for a fifth term, triggering a series of large peaceful protests called the "Hirak," which demanded not only his resignation, but also the dismantling of the existing political system. 

Faced with popular pressure and the withdrawal of army support, Bouteflika resigned on April 2, 2019.  However, his resignation did not fully meet the demands of the protest movement, which continued to call for deeper reforms. 

Abdelaziz Bouteflika passed away on September 17, 2021, after having left his mark on contemporary Algerian history.  His legacy remains complex, combining the success of reconciliation after the civil war with allegations of corruption, political repression, and poor economic management towards the end of his rule.
Omar al-Bashir:
Omar Hassan Ahmad al-Bashir (also known as Omar al-Bashir) is a Sudanese politician and military officer born on January 1, 1944 in Hosh Bannaga, northern Sudan.  He was the president of Sudan, serving for over three decades after coming to power in a military coup in 1989. 

Here is a summary biography:

**Youth and Military Career:**
Omar al-Bashir was born into a family with an agricultural background.  He joined the Sudanese army and quickly rose through the ranks due to his dedication and military skill.  He was trained in Egypt and Jordan and participated in several conflicts, including the long civil war between northern and southern Sudan. 

**Seizure of Power:**
On June 30, 1989, Omar al-Bashir, then a brigadier in the Sudanese army, led a coup that overthrew the democratically elected government of Sadiq al-Mahdi.  This coup was supported by the National Islamic Front led by Hassan al-Tourabi, with whom al-Bashir would have a relationship that alternated between cooperation and conflict. 

**Presidency:**
After the coup, al-Bashir became the head of state and the supreme commander of the armed forces.  He dissolved the government and the national assembly and banned political parties.  During his rule, he implemented a strict Islamist policy.  Sudan found itself isolated on the international stage, especially after the country offered refuge to figures such as Osama bin Laden in the 1990s. 

**Conflicts and Crises:**
The biggest stain on his presidency is the Darfur crisis that began in 2003, where allegations of ethnic cleansing and genocide were raised.  The conflict led to the deaths of hundreds of thousands of people and the displacement of several million others.  Sudan was also marked by the secession of South Sudan in 2011, after decades of civil war. 

**ICC Arrest Warrant:**
In 2009 and 2010, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issued two arrest warrants against al-Bashir for crimes against humanity, war crimes, and genocide committed in Darfur.  He thus became the first sitting president to be accused by the ICC. 

**Fall from Power:**
Al-Bashir's rule came to an end on April 11, 2019, when he was ousted by the military after months of mass protests against his government, focusing on issues of economic mismanagement, corruption, and political repression. 

**Post-Presidency:**
After his ouster, al-Bashir was imprisoned and faced multiple charges in his country, including corruption.  He is also the subject of an ongoing debate regarding his extradition to the ICC. 

**Legacy:**
The political and social legacy of Omar al-Bashir remains highly controversial, characterized by a long period of internal conflicts, international isolation, human rights violations, but also by an attempt at stabilization and national unity under a clearly Islamist vision of governance.  Sudan continues to face the consequences of his long and tumultuous rule. 

It is important to note that this biography is based on information available up until my last point of knowledge in 2023, and the legal situation or perception of Omar al-Bashir may have evolved beyond that date.
Abdelilah Benkirane:
Abdelilah Benkirane is a Moroccan political figure known for having been the head of the government of Morocco.  Born on April 4, 1954 in Rabat, Benkirane grew up in a middle-class family, with his father being a civil servant. 

He studied at Mohammed V University in Rabat where he obtained a degree in physics in 1976.  During his university years, Benkirane became politically involved, which led him to join the Islamist movement, contributing to the creation of the Al Islah wa Al Tajdid association, which later became the Popular Democratic and Constitutional Movement (MPDC). 

In 1983, Benkirane entered active politics by joining the National Popular Movement, which later merged with the MPDC to become the Justice and Development Party (PJD) in 1998.  He was elected as the party's secretary general in 2008. 

Under his leadership, the PJD won the legislative elections of 2011, a historic moment following the Arab Spring revolutions, which marked a turning point for politics in Morocco.  Following this victory, Benkirane was appointed as head of the government by King Mohammed VI, becoming the first Islamist politician to hold this position. 

His tenure as head of the government was characterized by economic and social reforms in the context of the demands of the International Monetary Fund and internal social protests.  These reforms included a controversial revision of the pension system and a reform of the compensation fund, intended to subsidize essential goods. 

However, his governance was not without controversy.  He had to navigate through a series of economic, social, and political crises, including demonstrations and strikes organized by various sectors of Moroccan society.

Benkirane is also known for his direct and often controversial style, frequently using simple and direct language, which makes him popular with some voters while irritating his critics.

Jos\u00e9 Eduardo dos Santos:
José Eduardo dos Santos was an Angolan politician who served as the second President of Angola since the country's independence in 1975.  He was born on August 28, 1942 in Luanda, in the Portuguese colony of Angola, and passed away on July 8, 2022 in Barcelona, Spain.  His presidential term, which lasted from 1979 to 2017, is one of the longest in African history. 

Dos Santos was raised in a family of Angolan and Congolese descent.  He received his early education in Angola before continuing his studies in Azerbaijan, in the Soviet Union at the time, where he studied petroleum engineering.  During his time in the USSR, he also began to get involved in political activities and joined the Angolan liberation movement. 

Upon returning to Angola, dos Santos joined the People's Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA), which was fighting against Portuguese colonial rule.  He held several positions within the MPLA and after Angola's independence in 1975, he served in various government roles, including as Minister of Foreign Affairs. 

Following the death of Angola's first president, Agostinho Neto, in 1979, José Eduardo dos Santos took over the leadership of the MPLA and consequently became President of Angola.  He took office in the midst of a civil war between the MPLA, backed by the Soviets and the Cubans, and the UNITA, supported by the United States and South Africa. 

During his tenure, dos Santos faced significant challenges, including managing the aftermath of the long civil war that only ended in 2002 with the death of UNITA's leader, Jonas Savimbi.  The civil war was devastating for Angola, causing hundreds of thousands of deaths and massive population displacement. 

After the war, dos Santos focused on rebuilding the country, heavily relying on oil and diamond revenues.  Despite impressive economic growth rates during his administration, his government was criticized for political repression, corruption, and poor distribution of the country's wealth. 

In terms of politics, José Eduardo dos Santos was known for his discreet but strategic leadership style.  He managed to maintain considerable power by consolidating his control over the MPLA and Angola's military and security structures. 

In 2017, dos Santos decided not to run for another term and passed the power to his chosen successor, João Lourenço.  However, even after leaving the presidency, he remained an influential figure within the MPLA and in Angola. 

Dos Santos made significant contributions to shaping modern Angola, and his legacy is marked both by stabilizing the country after a prolonged civil war and by criticisms regarding the management of national wealth and governance issues.
Filipe Nyusi:
Filipe Jacinto Nyusi is a Mozambican statesman born on February 9, 1959 in Namau in the district of Mueda, in northern Mozambique.  He has been the President of Mozambique since January 15, 2015. 

Nyusi comes from the ruling party, the Mozambique Liberation Front (FRELIMO), which has dominated Mozambican politics since independence from Portugal in 1975.  After obtaining his degree in mechanical engineering from the Industrial Institute of Brno in Czechoslovakia in 1990, he held various positions in the engineering and business sectors.

Before entering politics, Nyusi worked for the national railway company, Mozambique Railways (CFM), where he rose through the ranks to become the CEO of the group.  His political career began in 2008 when he became Minister of Defense in the government of former President Armando Guebuza. 

Within FRELIMO, Nyusi became known as a consensus builder and was selected to be the party's presidential candidate in 2014.  He won the 2014 presidential election with around 57% of the vote, succeeding Armando Guebuza.  His presidency has been marked by several challenges, including managing Mozambique's public debt and the armed conflict in the north of his country, involving militants linked to the Islamic State. 

In 2019, Nyusi was re-elected for a second term amid allegations of electoral fraud by the opposition.  Despite these political tensions, he has continued to work for the stability and development of Mozambique, while facing major natural disasters such as Cyclones Idai and Kenneth that hit Mozambique in March and April 2019, causing massive destruction and requiring significant international humanitarian response. 

Filipe Nyusi has also sought to attract foreign investment, particularly in the gas and oil sectors, with significant natural gas discoveries that could transform Mozambique's economy. As head of state, Nyusi represents a central figure in his country's efforts to maintain peace, promote national reconciliation, and stimulate economic growth.  His journey reflects the complexities of leadership in a country that continues to rebuild after decades of conflict while facing contemporary challenges.
John Mahama:
John Dramani Mahama is a Ghanaian politician born on November 29, 1958 in Damongo, in the northern region of Ghana.  He served as President of the Republic of Ghana from July 2012 to January 2017. 

Mahama began his education at "Achimota School" primary school in Accra before continuing his secondary education at "Ghana Secondary School" in Tamale.  He then obtained a Bachelor's degree in History from the University of Ghana, Legon, in 1981 and a postgraduate diploma in Communication from the same university in 1986.  Later, he studied at the Institute of Social Sciences in Moscow, Russia, where he obtained a diploma in Social Sciences. 

John Mahama initially worked as a teacher, then in communication, including as head of communication for an international NGO before entering politics.  He was first elected as a Member of Parliament under the National Democratic Congress (NDC) in 1996, representing the Bole district, a role he held for three terms until 2009. 

In 1997, he was appointed Deputy Minister for Communication, then Minister for Communication in 1998, a position he held until 2001.  In 2009, after NDC won the elections, John Mahama became Vice President under the presidency of John Evans Atta Mills. 

After President Mills' sudden death in July 2012, John Mahama succeeded him as President of Ghana, in accordance with the country's constitution.  He was elected for a full term in December 2012.  As President, Mahama focused on improving the country's infrastructure, including roads and schools, and launched the "Better Ghana Agenda" project, aimed at improving the lives of Ghanaian citizens in various sectors.

Hery Rajaonarimampianina:

During his tenure, he implemented policies aimed at stabilizing the Malagasy economy and restoring relations with international financial institutions.

However, his presidency faced several challenges, including accusations of corruption, clashes with parliament, and criticism regarding the management of democracy and freedom of expression in the country.

However, the High Constitutional Court ultimately rejected this attempt, allowing Rajaonarimampianina to remain in power. 

His term was also marked by efforts to improve the country's infrastructure and promote economic development, although these efforts were often hampered by internal political crises and difficulties in attracting significant foreign investments.

Paul Biya:
Paul Biya is a Cameroonian politician who has been the President of Cameroon since November 6, 1982.  He was born on February 13, 1933 in Mvomeka'a, Cameroon, which was then a French colony.  Here is a brief biography that traces his journey to his extended reign at the helm of Cameroon. 

Education and Early Career:
Paul Biya received a solid education, attending local primary and secondary schools before continuing his studies in France.  He studied in Saint-Claude in the Jura and in Paris, where he obtained a degree in public law from the Sorbonne and graduated from the Paris Institute of Political Studies (Sciences Po).  He later also graduated from the Institute of Higher Overseas Studies and the National School of Administration (ENA), a highly respected institution that trains senior French civil servants. 

Political Career under Ahidjo:
Upon returning to Cameroon, Biya entered public administration.  He held several positions and quickly rose through the ranks to become Director of Cabinet of the Ministry of National Education in 1964.  His administrative skills and political acumen allowed him to build a close relationship with the first Cameroonian president, Ahmadou Ahidjo.  In 1968, Biya was appointed Secretary-General of the Presidency of the Republic, and then Prime Minister in 1975.  These positions allowed him to gain fundamental governmental experience. 

Presidency:
When Ahidjo surprisingly resigned in 1982, he designated Paul Biya as his successor.  Biya then became the second President of Cameroon on November 6, 1982.  However, the relationship between Biya and Ahidjo quickly deteriorated, with political tensions leading to Ahidjo's conviction for plotting against President Biya. 

During his tenure, Paul Biya faced numerous challenges, including the need to manage Cameroon's ethnic diversity and tensions between the Francophone and Anglophone regions of the country.  He has also been criticized for his handling of human rights and corruption within his government. 

Reelections and Controversies:
Paul Biya has been reelected several times, often under controversial and contested conditions.  The elections of 1992, 1997, 2004, 2011, and 2018 were all marked by accusations of fraud and irregularities.  Biya's grip on Cameroonian political power has been facilitated by constitutional amendments that extended presidential terms and removed term limits, allowing him to remain in power. 

Domestic and Foreign Policy:
Internally, Biya's presidency has been marked by attempts to modernize the Cameroonian economy, with a focus on infrastructure development and increasing agricultural production.  Internationally, he has been generally recognized as a stable partner by Western powers and has played an important regional role in Central Africa. 

Now over 85 years old, Paul Biya is one of the longest-serving African leaders in power.  Despite recurring calls for retirement and democratic transition, he continues to lead Cameroon, with a firm grip on the country's political power.
Alassane Ouattara:
Alassane Dramane Ouattara is an Ivorian statesman, born on January 1, 1942 in Dimbokro.  Since December 4, 2010, he has been the President of the Republic of Côte d'Ivoire, reelected for a second term in 2015 and for a third term in 2020 under controversial circumstances.

After completing his secondary education in Côte d'Ivoire, he went to the United States where he obtained a Bachelor's degree in Economics from Drexel University in 1965, followed by a Master's and a PhD in Economics from the University of Pennsylvania in 1967 and 1972 respectively.

He later joined the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in 1968 where he held various positions before becoming Director of the African Department in 1984.  In 1987, he was appointed Governor of the Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO). 

In 1990, President Félix Houphouët-Boigny appointed him as Prime Minister of Côte d'Ivoire, a position he held until Houphouët-Boigny's death in 1993.  His attempt to run for the presidency in 1995 was thwarted by a nationality issue that sparked controversies in the Ivorian political context. 

After a period of work at the United Nations as Deputy Managing Director of the IMF, Alassane Ouattara returned to politics in Côte d'Ivoire.  He joined the Rally of the Republicans (RDR) and ran for the presidency again in 2010.  Following a controversial election and a bloody post-electoral crisis that resulted in thousands of deaths, he was eventually declared the winner and took office as President in May 2011, after the arrest of Laurent Gbagbo. 

His presidential term is characterized by a liberal economic policy that has led to high economic growth for the country, but also by criticism regarding the justice of the victors in the post-crisis management. Throughout his career, Alassane Ouattara has faced complex economic, political, and social challenges.  His presidency is both praised for its economic successes and criticized for his handling of political tensions and human rights issues.
Mahamadou Issoufou:
Mahamadou Issoufou is a Nigerian politician who served as the President of the Republic of Niger from 2011 to 2021.  Recognized as an engineer and statesman, he played a central role in Nigerien politics for several decades. 

Issoufou was born on January 1, 1952 in Dandadji, a small village in the Tahoua region of Niger.  He studied at the Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines de Saint-Étienne in France, where he obtained a degree in mining engineering in 1979. 

Upon returning to Niger after his studies, Mahamadou Issoufou began working for the Société des Mines de l'Aïr (SOMAIR), which exploits uranium - a key resource for the Nigerien economy.  His political engagement began in the 1980s within the trade union movement. 

With the advent of multipartism in the early 1990s, Issoufou co-founded the Nigerien Party for Democracy and Socialism (PNDS-Tarayya), of which he became the leader.  He served as Prime Minister under the presidency of Mahamane Ousmane from 1993 to 1994 before being removed following a vote of no confidence. 

As a political opponent for several years, he ran for the presidential election multiple times.  After being defeated in the 1993, 1996, and 1999 elections, and boycotting the 2009 elections, he finally won the presidency in 2011. 

His tenure as President of Niger was marked by efforts to strengthen democracy, combat corruption, and promote economic development.  He also faced significant security challenges, particularly the threat of extremist groups such as Boko Haram along the border with Nigeria. 

In 2016, Mahamadou Issoufou was reelected for a second term.  He continued his development policy focused on major infrastructure projects and some stabilization of the Nigerien economy despite a challenging regional security situation. 

Issoufou is known for his commitment to democratic principles, including respecting the constitutional limit of two presidential terms.  He did not seek to amend the Constitution to remain in power, unlike several other African leaders.  In 2021, his successor Mohamed Bazoum, also a member of the PNDS-Tarayya, took over after a democratically held presidential election, thus marking a peaceful transition of power. 

Mahamadou Issoufou has received several international accolades for his political actions, including the Ibrahim Prize for Achievement in African Leadership in 2020, which recognizes and honors outstanding African leaders who, during their tenure, develop their country, strengthen democracy, and uphold the rule of law.
Michel Kafando:
Michel Kafando is a Burkinabé diplomat and politician born on August 18, 1942 in Ouagadougou, now the capital of Burkina Faso.  Recognized for his role in the political transition of his country, he was President of the Transition of Burkina Faso from 2014 to 2015, following the Burkinabé revolution that led to the resignation of President Blaise Compaoré. 

After completing his secondary education in Burkina Faso, Kafando continued his academic path at university where he focused on international relations and law.  He obtained a Master's degree in public law from the University of Bordeaux in France, and furthered his studies in political science and international relations in France and Switzerland. 

His professional career has been largely dedicated to foreign affairs.  Before becoming President of the Transition, Michel Kafando had a long diplomatic career.  He first served as Burkina Faso's ambassador to the United Nations from 1998 to 2011.  Prior to that, he had held several positions within the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of his country, including serving as Minister of Foreign Affairs twice in the 1980s. 

His appointment as President of the Transition followed a popular uprising in late October 2014, which forced Blaise Compaoré to resign and leave the country after 27 years in power.  Michel Kafando was designated by a college of appointment including actors from civil society, religious leaders, opposition leaders, and other significant figures to lead a political transition intended to be neutral and independent. 

For nearly a year, Michel Kafando's mission was to lead Burkina Faso towards holding free and democratic elections.  His transitional mandate was also marked by attempted coups d'état and periods of instability, including a failed coup d'état in September 2015 led by the Presidential Security Regiment. 

Under his transitional administration, reforms were undertaken to strengthen democracy and the rule of law in Burkina Faso.  At the end of his mission in December 2015, general elections were organized, leading to the election of Roch Marc Christian Kaboré as president. 

Michel Kafando is recognized for his integrity and commitment to democracy and good governance.  After his role in the Burkinabé transition, he continues to be a respected figure in international and African diplomacy.
Ibrahim Boubacar Ke\u00efta:
Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta, often called IBK, was a Malian politician born on January 29, 1945 in Koutiala, Mali, and passed away on January 16, 2022 in Bamako.  He served as the President of the Republic of Mali from September 2013 to August 2020. 

Keïta began his career as a researcher in political science and as an international consultant.  After studying in France where he obtained a master's degree in history from the University of Paris I and a DEA (Advanced Studies Diploma) in political science from the Institute of Political Studies in Paris, he returned to Mali where he was involved in development projects. 

His political career gained momentum in the 1990s, following the fall of Moussa Traoré's regime.  Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta was appointed as Mali's ambassador to Côte d'Ivoire, and later served as Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1993 to 1994.  He became well known on the national political scene when he was appointed as Prime Minister under the presidency of Alpha Oumar Konaré, from 1994 to 2000.  During his tenure, he was credited with taking measures to strengthen Mali's economy and fight against corruption. 

In 2001, Keïta left the Alliance for Democracy in Mali (ADEMA) and founded his own party, the Rally for Mali (RPM).  He ran for president several times before winning in 2013.  His presidency was marked by increasing security challenges, including the insurgency in northern Mali led by jihadist groups and Tuareg rebels.  He was reelected in 2018 for a second term. 

However, his second term was cut short in August 2020, following a military coup after several months of public protests against his governance of the country.  Protesters criticized Keïta for his handling of the security crisis, the economy, and allegations of corruption. 

After the coup, Keïta was arrested by the military junta before being released.  He withdrew from active politics and passed away on January 16, 2022. 

Throughout his career, Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta was an influential figure in Malian politics, known for his eloquence and diplomatic experience.  However, his legacy is mixed due to the persistent security and economic issues in Mali during his administration and his inability to unite the country in the face of these challenges.
Barack Obama:
Barack Hussein Obama II was born on August 4, 1961 in Honolulu, Hawaii.  He is an American politician and the 44th President of the United States, serving from January 2009 to January 2017.  He is the first African American to have held this position. 

Barack Obama was born to a white American mother, Stanley Ann Dunham, from Kansas, and a black Kenyan father, Barack Obama Sr. , from Nyang'oma Kogelo.  His parents met while they were students at the University of Hawaii.  However, they separated when Obama was still young, and his father returned to Kenya, where he died in a car accident in 1982.  Obama was primarily raised by his mother, with occasional help from his maternal grandparents. 

During his childhood, Obama lived for a time in Indonesia with his mother and stepfather before returning to Hawaii to live with his grandparents and complete his high school education.  He went on to attend Occidental College in Los Angeles before transferring to Columbia University in New York, where he earned his degree in Political Science in 1983. 

After graduating, Obama worked for a time as a community organizer in Chicago.  He then continued his studies at the prestigious Harvard Law School, where he became the first black president of the Harvard Law Review.  After earning his law degree in 1991, he returned to Chicago to practice civil law while teaching at the University of Chicago Law School. 

Obama's political career began in 1997 when he was elected to the Illinois Senate, where he served for three terms.  In 2004, he gained national prominence with his speech at the Democratic National Convention, earning praise from members of his party.  In November 2004, he was elected to the United States Senate in a landslide victory. 

On February 10, 2007, Obama announced his candidacy for President of the United States.  He secured the Democratic nomination after a close race against Senator Hillary Clinton and defeated Republican Senator John McCain in the general election, becoming president on January 20, 2009.  During his tenure, he implemented major reforms such as the Affordable Care Act (also known as Obamacare), enacted financial reforms following the 2008 crisis, and ordered the military raid that led to the death of Osama bin Laden. 

Obama was reelected in 2012, defeating Republican candidate Mitt Romney.  His second term was marked by initiatives such as opening diplomatic relations with Cuba, the agreement on the Iranian nuclear program, and signing the Paris Climate Agreement. 

After leaving office in January 2017, Obama has remained active in politics and social issues through his Obama Foundation and other public initiatives.  His legacy remains enduring in American politics, and his leadership style and eloquence continue to inspire many Americans and people around the world.  He is married to Michelle Obama, with whom he has two daughters, Malia and Sasha.
Dilma Rousseff:
Dilma Vana Rousseff is a Brazilian politician born on December 14, 1947 in Belo Horizonte, in the state of Minas Gerais, Brazil.  The daughter of a Bulgarian immigrant and a Brazilian teacher, she grew up in a middle-class family with access to quality education.  Dilma Rousseff is best known for being the first female president of Brazil, with her term starting on January 1, 2011. 

Rousseff studied economics at the Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul.  In her youth, she was involved in the fight against the military dictatorship in Brazil (1964-1985), participating in various resistance movements.  Her political involvement led to her arrest in 1970 and to undergoing torture for nearly three years. 

After her release, Dilma Rousseff continued to work in the economic field and started her political career in the 1980s, following a general amnesty and the end of the dictatorship.  She held various positions such as Secretary of State for Economic Development, Energy, Mines, and Communication in the government of Rio Grande do Sul. 

Her national political career truly took off when she served as Minister of Energy and later as Chief of Staff under the presidency of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.  Her effective management and reputation as a rigorous administrator paved the way for her presidency. 

After being chosen as the candidate of the Workers' Party (PT), Rousseff won the presidential elections in 2010, succeeding Lula da Silva.  She focused on continuing the social policies initiated by her predecessor, and on managing energy and economic affairs.  Rousseff was re-elected in 2014 amidst growing political tension and amid protests against her government management and corruption scandals. 

Her second term was marked by a severe political and economic crisis.  In 2016, she was impeached for manipulating public accounts, a common practice in Brazil that was used as a political leverage by her opponents.  Dilma Rousseff was removed from office on August 31, 2016, following a vote by the Brazilian Federal Senate. 

Since her impeachment, Dilma Rousseff continues to engage in political activities and participates in conferences and debates on politics and democracy in Latin America and around the world, while rejecting the accusations that led to her removal, which she considers a parliamentary coup.
Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto:
Enrique Peña Nieto is a Mexican politician born on July 20, 1966 in Atlacomulco, in the State of Mexico.  A member of the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI), he served as President of Mexico from December 1, 2012 to November 30, 2018. 

Peña Nieto grew up in a family with a rich political tradition; his uncle, Alfredo del Mazo González, was governor of the State of Mexico.  After his studies, he obtained a law degree from the Panamerican University and a master's degree in Business Administration from the Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education (ITESM). 

He began his political career in his home state, initially working within his uncle's administration.  After holding various positions and assembling a vast political network, he was elected governor of the State of Mexico in 2005, a position he held until 2011, gaining national prominence during this time. 

His tenure as governor was marked by infrastructure, education, and health initiatives, as well as controversies, including allegations of corruption and media manipulation.  Despite these controversies, his image as a young technocrat and his focus on renewal helped propel him onto the national stage. 

In 2012, Peña Nieto was elected President of Mexico, promising to end the violence related to the war on drugs, modernize the Mexican economy, and implement structural reforms.  During his term, he implemented major energy, education, and tax reforms.  He also opened up the Mexican oil sector to foreign investment for the first time in decades. 

However, his administration was overshadowed by corruption scandals, notably the "Casa Blanca" affair, a high-value house linked to him and his first lady, Angelica Rivera.  Outrage was exacerbated by the handling of the case of the 43 missing students from Ayotzinapa in 2014, which sparked mass protests and international condemnation. 

In terms of foreign policy, Peña Nieto's relationship with the United States experienced highs and lows, especially after the election of Donald Trump as President of the United States and the tension surrounding immigration and the border wall issue. 

After leaving office, his reputation continued to suffer due to various investigations and accusations regarding his practices as president.  His party, the PRI, has since lost influence in Mexican politics, in part due to scandals associated with his administration. 

Enrique Peña Nieto has been married twice: first to Mónica Pretelini, with whom he had three children and who passed away in 2007, and then to actress Angelica Rivera, from whom he divorced in 2019 after years of marriage.
Juan Manuel Santos:
Juan Manuel Santos Calderón is a Colombian politician born on August 10, 1951 in Bogota.  Coming from an influential family in Colombian society, Santos played a central role in his country's politics during the early decades of the 21st century, notably serving as the President of Colombia from 2010 to 2018. 

Santos studied economics and business administration at the University of Kansas and earned a master's degree in economics from the London School of Economics, as well as a master's degree in public administration from Harvard University. 

In his political career, he first served as Minister of Foreign Trade under the government of César Gaviria in the 1990s.  He then served as Minister of Defense from 2006 to 2009 under President Álvaro Uribe, where he was recognized for his democratic security policy and led successful military operations against the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), including the Operation Jaque, which rescued Ingrid Betancourt and other hostages. 

Santos was elected President of Colombia in 2010, with an initial term lasting until 2014.  During his first term, he pursued a security policy while considering the possibility of negotiations with guerrilla groups.  His presidential tenure was also marked by significant social and economic reforms. 

In 2012, his government initiated peace talks with the FARC, leading to the signing of a historic peace agreement in 2016, ending over 50 years of armed conflict.  This agreement was initially rejected by a slim majority in a referendum, but was later modified and approved by the Colombian Congress.  For his efforts in achieving peace in Colombia, Santos was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2016. 

A less favorable aspect of his presidency was the economic difficulties and some disillusionment of the population regarding the outcomes of the peace agreements.  While the end of the armed conflict was celebrated internationally, many Colombians were concerned about the perceived impunity for former FARC combatants and the repercussions of the agreement on Colombian society. 

Reelected in 2014 for a second term, Santos continued to work on implementing the peace agreements and promoting national reconciliation, while facing significant challenges such as slow economic growth and an increase in cocaine production. 

After his presidency, Santos remained involved in various international initiatives and continues to contribute to dialogues on conflict resolution, sustainable development, and poverty alleviation. 

Juan Manuel Santos is a controversial figure in Colombia, revered by some for his role in the peace process, but criticized by others for the concessions made to the FARC and for the enduring internal issues in the country.
Cristina Fern\u00e1ndez de Kirchner:
Cristina Fernández de Kirchner is an Argentine politician who served as President of Argentina from 2007 to 2015.  She is one of the most prominent figures in modern Argentine politics and was the second woman to hold the country's presidency. 

She was born on February 19, 1953, in La Plata, Buenos Aires Province.  Cristina Fernández studied law at the National University of La Plata, where she met her husband, Néstor Kirchner.  Together, they played an active role in student politics during a period of great unrest and repression under the military regime in Argentina. 

After the end of the military dictatorship in 1983, Cristina Kirchner and Néstor Kirchner moved to Patagonia, where they entered politics under the banner of the Justicialist Party, which is generally associated with Peronism.  Cristina was elected as a deputy from the province of Santa Cruz in 1989 and quickly made a name for herself through her eloquence and commitment to human rights and social issues. 

In 1995, she became a senator, later alternating between the roles of senator and deputy.  She gained a reputation as a diligent legislator and charismatic speaker.  Meanwhile, Néstor Kirchner became governor of the province of Santa Cruz and later, in 2003, President of Argentina.  During her husband's presidency, Cristina Kirchner continued to play an influential role in politics. 

After Néstor Kirchner's presidential term, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner ran for the presidency and was elected in 2007.  Her presidency was characterized by progressive policies in economic and social areas, including strengthening social programs, increasing taxes on raw material exports, and promoting women's and minority rights.  Under her leadership, Argentina also nationalized some strategic enterprises. 

She faced various challenges during her term, including accusations of corruption, a conflict with the agricultural sector, and economic issues such as high inflation and currency exchange restrictions.  Despite these controversies, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner was re-elected for a second term in 2011. 

After leaving the presidency in 2015, Cristina Kirchner remained active in Argentine politics.  She faced several judicial accusations related to corruption allegations that marked her government and that of her husband.  Despite these controversies, she retains significant support in many sectors of Argentine society. 

In 2019, she made a surprising return to the political scene as a candidate for vice president alongside Alberto Fernández, who became president.  Her position continues to embody both the legacy of Kirchnerism in Argentine politics and a central pillar of the current opposition to the Republican Proposal (PRO), the party of her successor Mauricio Macri. 

Cristina Fernández de Kirchner is often recognized for her powerful rhetoric, direct style, and ability to mobilize her electoral base.  She continues to be an influential and sometimes polarizing figure in Argentine politics.
Justin Trudeau:
Justin Trudeau is a Canadian politician who has been serving as the Prime Minister of Canada since November 4, 2015.  Born on December 25, 1971 in Ottawa, Canada, he is the eldest son of former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Margaret Sinclair. 

Before entering politics, Justin Trudeau obtained a Bachelor's degree in English Literature from McGill University and a Bachelor's degree in Education from the University of British Columbia.  After his studies, he worked as a teacher in British Columbia, where he taught English literature, French, and mathematics. 

Trudeau's political career began in 2008 when he was elected as the Member of Parliament for the Papineau riding in Montreal for the Liberal Party of Canada.  He was re-elected in 2011 and began to gain national prominence. 

His rise in federal politics gained momentum in 2013 when he won the leadership of the Liberal Party.  He set out to revitalize the party, which was then in a difficult position after years of decline. 

As leader of the Liberal Party, Justin Trudeau has focused on issues such as the middle class, the rights of Indigenous peoples, combating climate change, and gender equality.  His campaign for the 2015 federal elections was marked by a message of hope and a commitment to positive change, which resonated widely with the Canadian electorate. 

On October 19, 2015, Justin Trudeau's Liberal Party won a parliamentary majority, propelling him to the position of Prime Minister of Canada.  His administration implemented measures such as the legalization of cannabis, the welcoming of Syrian refugees, and the introduction of a carbon tax to combat climate change.  Education and mental health are also areas he has sought to improve. 

In 2019, Trudeau's Liberal Party was re-elected but this time with a minority government, reflecting some controversies and a decline in popular support.  Despite this, he continues to lead the country through crucial moments, including managing the COVID-19 pandemic and its economic and social impacts. 

Outside of politics, Justin Trudeau has also been involved in various charitable causes.  He is married to Sophie Grégoire, a former television and radio host, and together they have three children.  Trudeau is recognized for his charisma, progressive approach to politics, and efforts to promote multiculturalism and inclusion in Canada.
Ollanta Humala:
Ollanta Humala is a Peruvian politician who was President of the Republic of Peru from 2011 to 2016.  Born on June 26, 1962 in Lima, Peru, Humala comes from a middle-class family with Andean roots and is the son of Isaac Humala, a lawyer and political activist of Indian ethno-nationalism. 

Military Career:
Before entering politics, Humala had a military career.  He served in the Peruvian army as an officer, specializing in artillery.  During his career, he participated in the fight against the Shining Path, a terrorist and Maoist group that waged a bloody insurgency against the Peruvian state. 

The Locumba Rebellion:
In 2000, Ollanta Humala first gained national attention following the Locumba rebellion, where he led an uprising, with his brother Antauro, against the government of the time to protest against corruption under the presidency of Alberto Fujimori.  However, this action failed, and Humala sought refuge in France before returning to Peru in 2001, following Fujimori's fall. 

Political Career:
His political career began when he founded the Peruvian Nationalist Party (Partido Nacionalista Peruano) in 2005.  A candidate in the 2006 presidential election, Humala ran a campaign focusing on the claims of the poor and on independence from foreign economic pressures, particularly against neoliberal policies.  However, he lost to Alan Garcia. 

In 2011, he ran for the presidency again.  This time, moderating his discourse and opting for a more centrist approach, he managed to win the election by defeating Alberto Fujimori's daughter, Keiko Fujimori, in a closely contested runoff. 

Presidency:
During his presidency, Ollanta Humala launched many social reforms aimed at reducing poverty and improving access to education and health for the Peruvian population.  However, his presidency was also marked by controversies, particularly regarding natural resource management strategies and conflicts with indigenous communities, as well as corruption scandals. 

After his presidency:
After the end of his term in 2016, Humala and his wife, Nadine Heredia, were accused of money laundering and corruption related to the extensive Odebrecht scandal that affected many Latin American countries.  They were detained preventively before being released in 2018 pending their trial. 

In summary, Ollanta Humala is a complex figure in early 21st-century Peruvian politics, who left his mark on the country by rising from military activism to the presidency and enduringly through his social policies, as well as legal controversies and corruption allegations that followed his presidency.
Nicol\u00e1s Maduro:
Nicolás Maduro is a Venezuelan politician born on November 23, 1962 in Caracas, Venezuela.  He is known for being the successor of Hugo Chavez and for being the President of Venezuela since 2013.  His political career has strongly developed under the socialist movement initiated by Chavez. 

Maduro started his career as a unionist in the public transport sector.  He was an active member of the Fifth Republic Movement (MVR), which supported Hugo Chavez's first presidential candidacy in 1998.  After Chavez's victory, Maduro quickly rose through the political ranks. 

In 2000, he was elected to the National Assembly, where he served until 2006.  During his term, he was recognized as a loyalist of Chavez and was appointed President of the Assembly in 2005.  In 2006, he was appointed Minister of Foreign Affairs of Venezuela, a position he held until 2013.  As minister, Maduro was a key figure in promoting Chavez's foreign policy, characterized by anti-American rhetoric and alignment with left-wing bloc countries. 

After Chavez's victory in the 2012 presidential election, Maduro was appointed Vice President of Venezuela.  When Chavez fell ill due to cancer, he designated Maduro as his successor in case he was unable to continue performing his duties.  This happened in March 2013, after Chavez's death, Maduro was appointed interim president. 

Maduro controversially won the subsequent presidential elections in April 2013, with a narrow margin against Henrique Capriles Radonski.  His presidency has been marked by a severe economic crisis, characterized by hyperinflation, food and medicine shortages, as well as the deterioration of living conditions for the Venezuelan population. 

Maduro's economic policies, as well as allegations of corruption and political repression, have led to massive protests across the country.  His legitimacy was challenged following the 2018 presidential elections, which were widely considered rigged by the opposition and many international observers. 

In January 2019, Juan Guaidó, President of the National Assembly and leader of the opposition, declared himself interim president of Venezuela, triggering a presidential crisis and an international debate on government recognition.  Many countries, including the United States and much of South America and Europe, have recognized Guaidó as the legitimate president, while Russia, China, Cuba, and other nations have continued to support Maduro. 

Nicolás Maduro has maintained power thanks to the support of the Venezuelan armed forces and the Supreme Court, loyal to the government.  His administration is often criticized for human rights abuses and the weakening of the country's democratic institutions.
Michelle Bachelet:
Verónica Michelle Bachelet Jeria was born on September 29, 1951 in Santiago, Chile.  She is not only known as an influential politician and a human rights activist, but she also made history by becoming the first woman to hold the presidency of Chile. 

The daughter of Air Force Brigadier General Alberto Bachelet and archaeologist Ángela Jeria, Michelle Bachelet witnessed from a young age a politically active environment, especially during the socialist government of Salvador Allende.  In 1973, following the military coup led by Augusto Pinochet, her father was arrested for treason and died in detention.  Michelle and her mother were also arrested and tortured by the regime's secret police before going into exile in Australia and then East Germany. 

She returned to Chile in 1979, where she studied medicine at the University of Chile, specializing in pediatrics and public health.  Throughout the 1980s, she was an active figure in opposition to Pinochet's dictatorship. 

After the restoration of democracy in Chile in 1990, Michelle Bachelet became an important figure within the socialist party.  She held various government positions, including Minister of Health and later Minister of National Defense under the presidency of Ricardo Lagos, becoming the first woman to hold this position in Latin America. 

She was first elected president of Chile in January 2006, as the candidate of the center-left coalition Concert of Parties for Democracy.  Her term focused on social reforms, including protecting women's rights, pension reform, and improving social security.  After completing her first term in 2010, she was appointed the first executive director of UN Women, a United Nations entity dedicated to gender equality and women's empowerment. 

In 2013, Michelle Bachelet was re-elected president of Chile, promising a series of major reforms, including a overhaul of the constitution inherited from the Pinochet era, but faced challenges in implementing them.  Despite significant advancements, such as the reform of the education system, her second term was overshadowed by economic problems and corruption scandals that affected public opinion. 

After leaving the presidency in March 2018, she continued her career in global affairs.  In August 2018, she was appointed United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, where she worked on key issues such as the human rights crisis in Venezuela and the treatment of Uighurs in China. 

Michelle Bachelet is respected for her commitment to public service and her enduring role in promoting human rights and equality.  Her leadership has had an impact not only in Chile but also on the international stage.
Otto P\u00e9rez Molina:
Otto Fernando Pérez Molina is a Guatemalan politician and military man born on December 1, 1950 in Guatemala City.  He was the President of the Republic of Guatemala from January 14, 2012, to September 3, 2015, before resigning due to corruption charges. 

Pérez Molina began his career in the Guatemalan army.  He was trained at the School of the Americas and held various positions within the military institution, especially during the long Guatemalan civil war that lasted from 1960 to 1996.  He rose through the ranks to become a Brigadier General and was directly involved in the peace process that ended the conflict. 

After retiring from the army in 2000, he co-founded the center-right political party Patriotic Party (Partido Patriota) and entered politics.  Pérez Molina ran for the presidency for the first time in 2007 but was defeated in the second round.  He ran again in the presidential election of 2011 and won by promising a tough stance on crime and a "firm hand" ("mano dura") strategy against organized crime and drug trafficking. 

However, his tenure was overshadowed by allegations of corruption.  In 2015, a criminal investigation led by the International Commission against Impunity in Guatemala (CICIG), assisted by the Public Ministry of Guatemala, resulted in charges against several high-ranking officials in the Pérez Molina administration for their alleged involvement in a vast customs corruption network known as the "La Línea Case. " Faced with popular pressure and massive protests, Pérez Molina resigned from the presidency on September 3, 2015, and the following day, he was arrested for his alleged involvement in the corruption network. 

After his resignation, Alejandro Maldonado Aguirre succeeded him as interim president until the election of Jimmy Morales. 

The case raised broader questions about endemic corruption in Guatemalan governance and strengthened the role of the CICIG and similar organizations in combating impunity in Latin America. 

Otto Pérez Molina was imprisoned and placed in preventive detention pending his trial.  His legal affairs have been closely monitored both nationally and internationally, as they are emblematic of the challenges facing Latin American countries in establishing the rule of law and combating systemic corruption.
Rafael Correa:
Rafael Vicente Correa Delgado is an Ecuadorian politician born on April 6, 1963 in Guayaquil.  He was president of the Republic of Ecuador from 2007 to 2017, becoming one of the most important and controversial political figures in the country's recent history thanks to his left-wing policies, known as the "citizens' revolution. "

Correa grew up in Guayaquil and studied economics at the Catholic University of Santiago de Guayaquil.  He continued his studies in Belgium and the United States, earning a master's degree in economics from the Catholic University of Louvain and a Ph. D.  in economics from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. 

He began his career as a university professor in Ecuador, but his involvement in politics started to gain importance after his return from the United States.  In 2005, he was appointed Minister of Economy under the government of Alfredo Palacio, but he resigned a few months later, citing differences with the government's economic policies. 

In 2006, he ran for president of Ecuador as a candidate of the Alianza PAIS movement, which he had helped found a year earlier.  Correa won the elections by promoting a socialist agenda aimed at reducing poverty, increasing public services, and renegotiating oil contracts to increase state revenues.  His approach also included a critical stance towards the United States and international financial institutions like the International Monetary Fund (IMF). 

Once in office, Correa launched a series of reforms to implement his vision of the "citizens' revolution. " He strengthened the state's role in the economy, increased social spending, and introduced laws to control the media, leading to accusations of restrictions on press freedom.  He also convened a constituent assembly that drafted a new constitution for the country, enacted in 2008. 

Correa's government experienced three successive terms, a notable political and electoral stability for Ecuador, often characterized by instability in these areas.  However, his administration was also marked by accusations of corruption and criticism regarding his authoritarian style of governance. 

Although he left power in 2017, not seeking a fourth term, Rafael Correa remained a central figure in Ecuadorian politics.  His decision to move to Belgium after his term was partly due to judicial investigations into corruption allegations against him in his homeland. 

Correa has tried to remain politically active by supporting political allies in Ecuador and through comments on social media and media appearances.  He has consistently opposed the policies of his initially endorsed successor, Lenín Moreno, thus revealing tensions within the Alianza PAIS movement and demonstrating the deep divisions within the Ecuadorian left after his departure from the presidency.
Evo Morales:
Evo Morales, whose full name is Juan Evo Morales Ayma, is a Bolivian politician born on October 26, 1959 in Isallavi, in the department of Oruro in Bolivia.  Coming from the Aymara indigenous community, he was the first president of the country to belong to an indigenous ethnicity, and his presidency marked a period of major social and political transformations for Bolivia. 

Morales grew up in a subsistence farming family and started working at a young age to help his parents.  In the 1980s, after serving in the Bolivian army, he became involved in coca cultivation and in the coca growers' unions, which were often in conflict with the Bolivian government due to the US-supported drug eradication policy. 

As a union leader, Morales established himself as a defender of coca farmers' rights and indigenous populations.  He began his political career within the Movement for Socialism (MAS), a party that merged the interests of coca farmers, indigenous groups, and other marginalized segments of Bolivian society. 

Morales was elected president of Bolivia in 2005 and took office in 2006.  During his presidency, Bolivia underwent significant reforms, including the nationalization of the gas and oil industry, efforts to reduce poverty, and a more equitable distribution of the country's income.  He also played a key role in drafting the new Bolivian constitution in 2009, which strengthened the rights of indigenous peoples and allowed for presidential reelection. 

Morales was reelected in 2009 and in 2014 for a controversial third term, after obtaining a decision from the Constitutional Court allowing him to run despite the term limits set in the Bolivian constitution.  His attempt to stay in power for a fourth term in 2019 triggered a political crisis and protests following allegations of electoral fraud.  Under pressure from the military, the police, and large sectors of the population, Morales resigned and initially went into exile in Mexico, then in Argentina.

Ra\u00fal Castro:

Horacio Cartes:

Daniel Ortega:
José Daniel Ortega Saavedra was born on November 11, 1945 in La Libertad, Nicaragua.  He is a Nicaraguan politician who has played a central role in the recent history of his country.  As a member of the national leadership of the Sandinista National Liberation Front (FSLN), Ortega was a key figure in the struggle against the dictatorship of the Somoza family that ruled Nicaragua for decades.

In 1984, Ortega was elected President of Nicaragua.  His first term was marked by left-wing policies, social and economic reforms, but also by a civil war against the "Contras," anti-communist armed groups supported by the United States.  Despite reform efforts, the country's economy suffered under the weight of U. S.  embargoes and the costs of the civil war.

Daniel Ortega's biography is that of a man who began as a revolutionary and became one of the most enduring and controversial political figures in Latin America.  His legacy remains complex and widely debated both in Nicaragua and internationally.
Tony Abbott:
Tony Abbott is an Australian politician who served as the 28th Prime Minister of Australia from September 18, 2013, to September 15, 2015.  Born on November 4, 1957, in London, United Kingdom, Abbott moved to Australia with his family in 1960.  He held dual British and Australian citizenship until 1993 when he renounced his British citizenship to comply with the Australian Constitution and start his political career. 

Educated in Catholic schools in Sydney, he later obtained a Bachelor of Economics and a Bachelor of Laws from the University of Sydney.  After completing his degrees, he became a Rhodes Scholar and continued his studies at Queen's College, Oxford University in the United Kingdom, where he earned a Master of Arts in Politics and Philosophy. 

Upon returning to Australia, Abbott initially worked as a journalist before shifting to politics.  He became the executive director of Australians for Constitutional Monarchy before entering politics as a member of the Liberal Party.  In 1994, he was elected to the House of Representatives for the Warringah electorate in Sydney. 

Abbott held several ministerial positions under John Howard's government, including Minister for Employment, Minister for Workplace Relations, and Minister for Health.  He is known for his conservative views, particularly on social issues such as opposition to abortion and same-sex marriage, as well as his support for the monarchy and skepticism towards climate change. 

Following the Liberal Party's defeat in 2007, Abbott became a key figure in the opposition.  He was elected leader of the Liberal Party in December 2009, narrowly defeating incumbent Malcolm Turnbull.  As opposition leader, he criticized the policies of the Labor Party government, particularly in economic management and carbon tax. 

Tony Abbott became Prime Minister after his party's victory in the 2013 federal elections.  His tenure was characterized by conservative stances, controversial budget cuts, and harsh immigration policies, including the implementation of Operation Sovereign Borders to deter refugee boat arrivals.  His popularity suffered due to various political decisions and media gaffes, leading to a loss of support within his own party. 

In September 2015, Abbott was ousted through a leadership vote within the Liberal Party and replaced by Malcolm Turnbull.  After his removal from leadership, he remained in politics as a member of parliament before retiring ahead of the 2019 federal elections, where his seat was won by an independent candidate. 

Outside of politics, Tony Abbott is known for his involvement in community activities, including volunteering in rural fire services and as a sea rescuer. Following his political career, Abbott continued to engage in public debates and assumed various roles, including serving as a special trade envoy and advisor to the British government on trade post-Brexit.
John Key:
John Phillip Key, born on August 9, 1961 in Auckland, is a New Zealand businessman and politician, a member of the National Party and Prime Minister of New Zealand from 2008 to 2016.  His mixed career in finance and politics has allowed him to become known both nationally and internationally. 

Childhood and Education:
John Key grew up in social housing in Auckland, raised by his mother after the death of his father, who was an English Jewish immigrant.  He studied at the University of Canterbury, where he earned a Bachelor of Commerce degree in 1981. 

Career in Finance:
After university, Key started working as an accountant for a clothing company in New Zealand.  He then entered the financial sector, building a career in international investment banks such as Merrill Lynch, specializing in foreign exchange operations.  He climbed the ranks to become at one point the Global Head of Foreign Exchange and became one of the directors of Merrill Lynch. 

Entry into Politics:
John Key entered the political scene in 2002 when he was elected as a Member of Parliament for the National Party representing the Helensville electorate.  His rise was swift, and in 2006, he succeeded Don Brash as the leader of the National Party. 

Prime Minister of New Zealand:
Key led the National Party to victory in the 2008 election, emphasizing his success in business and promising to implement an effective response to the global financial crisis.  As Prime Minister, he pursued policies focused on economic strengthening both nationally and promoting free trade.  He was re-elected in 2011 and 2014, showing a certain popularity among New Zealand voters. 

During his tenure, New Zealand experienced significant events such as the Christchurch earthquake in 2011, and Key undertook initiatives such as education reform, reconstruction in Christchurch, and signing several free trade agreements, including the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP).  Key was also recognized for his moderate stances on social issues such as same-sex marriage, which he supported. 

Resignation:
To the surprise of many, John Key announced his sudden resignation as Prime Minister and leader of the National Party in December 2016, citing personal reasons and a desire to spend more time with his family.  His resignation was widely seen as a departure at the height of his popularity. 

Post-Politics:
Since his political retirement, Key has returned to the private sector and taken on roles in various boards of directors.  His ability to navigate between finance and politics has solidified his legacy as one of the most influential leaders of New Zealand in his time.
